I was curious at first why they would choose Layonna's meatless drumsticks as the main ingredient for a sandwich. The first bite told me why. Each bite is loaded with flavor from the large chunks of chewy goodness. The only place that takes better advantage of these wings is Thai Idea in their "Wing bomb" The crusty, dusty, Acme bread really sets the sandwich apart from the rest out there

No seating that I saw except near the counter, but you'll be calling in your order to go anyway, right? As for the rest of the deli it seemed they had a pretty good selection of chips and drinks if that's what you're looking for. Sando + chips was $10.26 I believe. Not cheap at all but highly worth it!
author: John B.

description: Called in an order. Showed a half hour later and paid. I was asked to wait as they were behind. After 45 minutes and several check in (where I was told My order was in the cue) I realized they had lost it completely. Poor customer service.
author: Giuseppe C.

description:
I've been here a total of three times now and feel very comfortable giving this place 4 stars. You are not going to get a "high end, luxurious" sandwich such as Darwin's... more of the blue collar type with a shimmy twist. Here's what I've sample so far

The Harrison - $7.45 -  Hot Pastrami with cheddar cheese, red onions, lettuce, tomatoes, pickles, pepperoncini with spicy mustard and chipotle aioli. I believe the meat is Boar's head which is always a good thing. Not excessively lined with fat yet not too lean where it's completely dry. All the veggies were fresh and there was only a hint of the mustard. Very mild spice from the chipotle. Their acme organic rolls is also very tasty.

Marinated Veggie Steak - $7.45 - This was a true surprise. I'm usually not a big fan of meat substitutes but this is the real deal. The flavor and texture is almost like a Korean marinated meatball. I could eat this and not feel like a wimp! I can't remember the veggies, but I believe it has lettuce, tomatoes and pickles with possible a garlic aioli. 

Korean Steak Sandwich - $8.99 - One of the more popular sandwiches so I had to try it, plus who doesn't like ribeye slices in a sandwich? The meat has been marinated in a soy sauce garlic, ginger, honey and other spices. I didn't takes a lot of ginger which is a plus for me, and it did just have a hint of the honey. The veggies included is lettuce and a very nice pickled red onion with jalapenos and fresh red onions. The sammie is sauced up with their garlic aioli on the organic acme roll. I can see why this is popular, it's quite good especially if you like spicy steak sandwiches.

I'll be back here at least a couple more times. Since their Veggie Steak was really good, they have another vegetarian sammie, the Vegetarian BBQ Chicken which comes with some a chicken drumstick, red/white cabbage with carrots, pickled red onions (yum!), jalapenos, chili garlic sauce and roasted red pepper aioli for $8.19
author: Andrew L.

description:
Places like this is seriously what Yelp was made for. 

I would have never thought that this totally unassuming liquor store (with an awesome selection of 40'z btw), would have the best, if not THE ONLY...... Korean steak sandwich in the world. Take that LA! 

I knew I needed to come here after reading yelp friend Lolia S's review. She seriously puts in foodie work and she's right about the Korean steak sandwich being a masterpiece. 

Sweet, savory, spicy, crazy, sexy, cool.....  The Korean steak sandwich completely creates an addictive taste and flavor sensation. 

Marinated steak (honey, soy sauce, spices), garlic aioli, hot sauce + pickled jalapeno, with three types of onions, on a warmed acme roll, coughing, sneezing, so you can sleep medicine! This sandwich IS the Nyquil that puts my man food appetite to rest. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=8OX0OsarCVwtHx0H2M3pXw)

I'm going in for Rhea-tox next week.
author: Earl G.

description: I've had the Korean Steak and Chicken Katsu on separate occasions. Wait wasn't too long either times I went, but that was during off peak hours. Parking nearby can take awhile so I factor that into whether or not it's worth it to come. Overall, pretty tasty for both sandwiches. A bit pricier than I prefer and eating it can get messy as they are huge.
author: Rick T.

description: Everything here is awesome! The staff is great, they have veggie, vegan, and meat sandwiches. They get pretty busy, so I unusually phone in my order.
author: Bailey S.

description:
My work team and I have been on the hunt for SF's best sandwich.  Every week now it seems, we've hit up at least 2 new places hoping to hit the goldmine inbetwixt two slices of bread.  yes, i said inbetwixt.

Rhea's is a non-assuming deli on Valencia aka what I call SF's Gourmet Ghetto. It's a small place, nothing that sets it apart from the city's other 936,000 deli's except...they have, in my most humblest of opinions, the city's best sandwich the Korean Steak Sandwich.  Maybe it's because I've been craving bulgogi lately, but man, when I took my first bite, it was like an angel was playing Canon in D Major on a harp in the background, and another angel on the Alto Sax, and of course another angel playing a TAMA Starclassic drumset.  It was seriously like heaven.

Acme sweet roll - chewy on the outside, soft on the inside
Ribeye, sliced thin - it's Ribeye people! come on!
topped off with chili garlic sauce and a whole mess of onions
cheese - i chose swiss
and some lettuce for crunch.

It was a bit pricey and the sandwich, imo, was a bit small for the price, but you won't find a more flavorful sandwich in SF

I'm telling you son, git you some!
author: Ray R.

description:
Saw this place on "Check Please."   It almost lived up to the hype.  The Korean steak sandwich was very tasty.  I got it "medium," which was PLENTY spicy. ( I have no idea why anyone would bother with the "spicy" option because I doubt you could taste the food with your mouth on fire.)

  The Katsu sandwich was much less impressive, and I won't order it again.  It could have been shoe leather in there, and I wouldn't really have noticed.  Not that it would have been bad though.

    The gimmick or the "hook" with these sandwiches is the excellent bread (Acme), (which is half the battle when it comes to sandwiches), and then the variety of ingredients/condiments added.  So every bite is a bit different and never boring.  When they add chili sauce, garlic aioli, jalapenos, pickled red onions, and a variety of veggies, it would be hard NOT to make something interesting.  So even though the "spicy goo" covers up some of the flavors, I'd be a regular if I lived in the area.

      I also got the regular kimchi, and it was one of the better ones I've tasted.  Nothing to rave about, just solid.

    As far as the place, it's a divey, liquor store.  Oh, and parking is friggin' ridiculous, as I circled for about 10 minutes to find a place about 4 blocks away.  Now I know why people park illegally...to save their sanity.
author: Chris C.

description: Great takeaway sandwich place. Takes a few min to make the sandwich, so I'd recommend ordering in advance if you're in a real hurry. Perfect stop on your way to Dolores Park, though.
author: Kyle K.

description:
I've recommended this place to others but was recently reminded that I forgot to write my own review until now. Late last year's remodel of the deli counter section at this corner grocery store, was the turning point that made it a worthwhile destination to get some awesome sandwiches.

The grocery store stocks your typical convenience items: sodas, juices, alcoholic drinks, snacks, basic household products, etc. Plus deli meats (about $11.99/lb.) and a variety of gourmet cheeses including Cowgirl Creamery's triple-cream cheese.

The deli offers standard sandwiches using Boar's Head brand deli meats ($5-5.50) and about 10 special sandwiches ($6.50-7.95). The most popular items are the Korean beef ($7.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rheas-deli-and-market-san-francisco?select=7iAjXA7tYfytvakvEHINVw#7iAjXA7tYfytvakvEHINVw and the pork katsu ($6.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rheas-deli-and-market-san-francisco?select=rBdVB12S1t90nfcWn1aalg#rBdVB12S1t90nfcWn1aalg sandwiches. Chicken katsu is also available (handwritten in a post-it next to the taped menu). I'm partial to the beef. The meat is reheated in a microwave before assembly, the juices soak into the bread. You get your choice of cheese and bread.

Korean beef tacos ($3.35 each, or 2 for $6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rheas-deli-and-market-san-francisco?select=sHT7stzrBWei8WUBNXs8cQ is a recent addition. They are almost identical to Taco Bell soft tacos, except for the Korean beef flavor (using a flour tortilla plus a spread of refried beans to keep the beef from falling out - clever idea). It falls apart as u bite into it, and a little messy to eat. Get extra napkins. Good taste, but no real competition to Korean tacos from Namu or others.

The grocery store is open 8am to midnight (until 2am on Fri-Sat), but Deli hours are 11am-7pm (8pm Fri & weekends).
author: Luis C.

description:
I was able to grab a great sandwich here. Definitely more a place to take a sandwich to go, although they have benches in the front. Just not how I roll. 

I had a hard time choosing a sandwich online, but ended up with the 19th Street. I had walked by before and noticed how spread out the menu was (the reason I didn't stop in that day) so I was sure to check it out. Thankfully, my sandwich was available, a few options were out. Also, some of the sandwiches are no longer made with the local pastrami as listed online. I saw only on description that way in store. Not sure if they are no longer using it, or? 

The ordering is also a little weird for first timers. Don't walk to the sandwich guys! Grab an order sheet first. Then, once you make your selection, grab a drink and head to the register. The order goes in after you pay. 

All in all, the sandwich was really good. Just not feeling like it was great enough for the hype and it probably won't go into the regular rotation.
author: Angel G.

description:
First things first... they serve Boars Head deli meats.  Always the best option if you get your meats from a grocery store and always the worst if you get them from an Italian deli or butcher.  Rhea's Market isn't italian nor a butcher... with that out of the way...

Now THAT'S how you serve Boars Head Deli Meats!!

I walked in and order right away...turns out there's usually a wait.  So I got lucky with my timing, however I struggled with trying to decide what to order... there are some really good sandwiches on the menu.  I decided to get two completely different flavors. Went with the Harrison St (Pastrami, cheese, peppers, chipotle aioli) and Korean Steak Sandwich (marinated steak, cheese, chili garlic sauce, pickled onions and grilled onions).  I originally wanted to eat half of both and leave the rest for later...but no...didn't happen...devoured both in one sitting.

Now have to be back for dinner...and lunch again tomorrow.  I'll be thinking about what to get all night... this menu requires planning.

And to the folks here from Chicago...they have REAL giardiniera...IN OIL.  Not the healthy west coast crap (in water) we have to put up with.  I'm so happy...

Fantastic sandwiches and everyone there is really friendly.  Can't wait to be back.
author: Zoran L.

description:
You know those nights when its cold, the bars are packed with people who you wouldn't want to have a drink around even if you were paid for it, you're tired, hungry, and early for an appointment? I had one of those last Friday, and walking down Valencia Street, seeing bar after bar filled with "Woo" people, and not in the financial straits to go for a sit down dinner, I decided on Rhea's, a longstanding fixture in the Mission and on my "bookmarks" list.

Like everyone else in the world, I ordered The Korean Steak Sandwich (9.95), which was pretty damn tasty, and kind of problematic. They certainly didn't skimp on delicious, ginger and soy marinated steak, and the well toasted, gloriously crunchy ciabatta roll did no harm. The pickled onions and jalapenos perhaps too acidic, the cheese unmelted, but when taken together with a potent spice which skittered along my tongue like Saint Elmo's fire over the mast of a ship, and a rich garlic mayo, I can totally understandable how Rhea's could get away with charging ten dollars for this sandwich. Its the sort of combination which hits every human need for spice, acidity, protein, fats, and carbs in just the right way, and leaves you craving for more. I can't give it five stars, but it comes pretty damn close. 

With sandwich in hand, I grabbed a bomber of Lagunitas from their cabinet (in a classy-as-fuck-paper bag), went out on the street, and inhaled my meal in a parklet while the endless parade of hip, tech folk walked past. At that moment, I was far happier outside on a cold night then I would have been in one of the crowded bars with fogged windows on every corner.

Overall: Four Stars. A somewhat problematic, but praiseworthy sandwich.

Extras:

Beers are a bit overpriced (by about a dollar)

Accessible to all Mission corridor bus lines, BART, the 33-Stanyan and 22-Fillmore.
author: Casey U.

description:
Yeah yeah yeah Korean steak sandwich blah blah blah with a pork katsu thrown in every once in a while. Once you've read one review for Rhea's, you've read them all. I don't need to tell you how AMAZEBALLS the aforementioned are since everyone else does a pretty good job with it, but I can say that it is definitely worth trying the other sandwiches and that I highly encourage other Yelpers to talk about them to give more balanced and helpful reviews.

For instance: I am currently indulging in a delicious Gargamel sandwich filled with (quoting from their menu) "grilled sweet soy and garlic-marinated chicken with housemade jicama slaw in vinaigrette, garlic aioli on toasted rosemary ciabatta." Now doesn't that sound YUMMY? Well it is!!! The jicama slaw has carrots in it and reminds me of the pickled veggies they put in banh mi. There's also some kind of lettuce that I think is baby romaine. And the chicken is excellent and different.

There ya go! Try something new at Rhea's.

Also, some quick updates as of 1/5/12 at 2:13pm PST:

*They're NOT selling either the pork or chicken katsu for an indefinite amount of time it seems, so don't even try. Yeah, I was pretty bummed too. 

*They used to do a jar deposit with their nomilicious kim chee, but they apparently don't anymore. So basically I wasted two extra bucks the first time I bought kim chee here and didn't need to bring back the empty jar today. I think it costs $6.99 now.

*They still are always crowded and only getting crowded-er, so do yourself a favor and call ahead. They also run out of sandwiches frequently, so get your butt up early to dial in your sando!
author: Kate V.

description:
This spot is legit. Quality ingredients, chill atmosphere. I got the "19th" which has roast beef, garlic aioli and other good shit. They use all Boar's head ingredients.

This is one of those deli shops that you probably won't even walk into unless you're a local. Try it out for yourself. It doesn't look super big by appearance but it's packed and I was pretty satisfied after I was done.
author: Mike P.

description: I love Rhea's and Salumeria both as great sandwich spots in the mission that I frequent. The fried chicken sandwich and fish tacos here are absolutely perfect. Bulgogi sandwich also very tasty. Would not make any changes to those! Minus one star because their vegetarian fake chicken sandwich is only ok and their sweet potato fries are sometimes one the soggy side. To compare, salumeria has more salad options and much more seating but doesn't have a frier as far as I can tell. So if you are in the mood for any kind of hot meat Rhea's is the better bet!
author: Erin C.

description:
I am now officially a believer. Rhea's makes one of the most delicious sandwiches I have ever had! I chose the korean steak sandwich and it was just the right combination of juicy steak, spicy sauce and sweet roll. The line can get pretty long during lunch-time, but they take their time crafting each sandwich to perfection. Make sure to eat it as soon as possible since the juiciness of the steak does tend to soak the bread after awhile.

Pro-tip: Walk a few blocks and enjoy a summer afternoon in Dolores with your sandwich!
author: Dennis R.

description:
A hidden gem on Valencia, this has become one of my favorite spots for sandwiches. Looking like just another corner liquor store, Rhea's Deli & Market is home to some of the most delicious sandwiches the Mission has to offer.

Their Korean Steak Sandwich is an all-time favorite and certainly deserves to be! The Marinated Rib-Eye soaked in soy sauce, garlic, honey & spices will work wonders on your taste buds. The pairing of the cheddar cheese is odd at first but gives an interesting texture in the end. The pickled red onions, jalapeños, garlic aioli and shredded iceberg lettuce all compliment the Rib-Eye. I really like the Acme Organic bread roll it's served on because it's the bread's texture and fluff if just right. A soft inside with a doughy, semi-crunch. I order mine spicy because I enjoy the hotness.

Other sandwiches I've enjoyed here are the 18th St. (Hot Buffalo chicken, muenster cheese, bacon) and the Lexington (Honey Maple & Black Ham, swiss cheese, pickled jalapeños).

Most of their sandwiches have the garlic aioli sauce. You can also mix and match the bread rolls (Sweet, Herb, Dutch Crunch, Ciabatta).

A winning sandwich haven that also has a bunch of beers, sodas, juices and liquors to choose from. An ultimate hipster spot, this Deli Market is simply AWESOME.
author: Andrew C.

description: Market style deli with great sandwiches.  They make their own pastrami which is great.  My recent favorite is the Korean steak sandwich with kimchi.  Limited bar seating in the back of the market.  Call ahead during lunch time to avoid the wait.
author: Dinesh P.

description:
Damn, Rhea. Girl, you make a fine sandwich. 

That dang Korean steak sandwich on dutch crunch with kimchi, spicy mayo, pickled red onions, lettuce and melted cheddar cheese... I'm pretty sure if you saw me devouring it in Dolores that you would have thought I hadn't ate in years.

My sandwich + kombucha were $15, which is a price within the realm of reason. I paid with cash because their machines were down, so have some on you just in case. They said it'd take 15 mins to come out, but it took 10. That's it-- take your fine ass sandwich to the park. 

Just look at this beautiful thang http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=VCYtRcED5pBCZBwhEUI8Nw
author: K M.

description:
I had a godfather sandwich. It was delicious! It's a cold sandwich with good meat and good sauce yummmm!!! 

I wish I had checked it out on yelp first before ordering the godfather because I think I'd like a warm BBQ Sandwich better... 

My friend Lauren loved the Dutch Crunch Bread. She gives 5 star. She thinks it's the better version of thanksgiving.
author: Song Z.

description: Probably my favorite sandwich spot in the city.  They make me happy, all meaty and stuff.  The weight can be a pain and they don't offer the same selection of sandwiches at both locations.  Other than that, they are solid and the cashiers are always very pleasant and chill.
author: Shaun C.

description:
The vege-steak sandwich is the best sandwich I've ever had. Sorry, Ike's. The fake meat was delicious, and it was loaded with all of my favorites: caramelized red onions, pickled jalapenos, and pepperjack all swimming in spicy garlic aioli sauce. This was one of the specials advertised on the front door, and usually I don't order off the menu, but from now on I will trust the masters behind the deli counter.

There's still plenty to choose from for drinks and snacks. I wish there wasn't a $10 minimum for credit cards. Do yourself a favor, grab food here, walk a block down to Dolores, and enjoy the best lunch you could get in San Francisco.
author: Cat N.

description:
A solid 4 stars.  The Korean Steak Sandwich does not disappoint.  It's packed with flavor and has a nice spicy kick to it.  I went mild and it was more than enough spiciness for me.  But if you like hotness, you can definitely up it to medium or HOT.  I don't know what it was, but the spiciness lingered well after I finished my sandwich.  It only went away after I got my hands on a stick of gum.  The organic Acme roll is good.  The pickled red onions, lettuce, and grilled onions are all delish.  I didn't specify a cheese and I guess the default is cheddar because that's what I got.  It wasn't bad.  There was a definite contrast in the texture of the cheese versus the tenderness of the meat, but it wasn't a deal breaker.  I think next time, if available, I'd opt for some melted provolone instead.  Oooh, now that sounds good!

The drive here from Mission Bay wasn't far, but definitely time-consuming.  I hate spending half my lunch hour driving so I'm not sure I'd come back on a work day.  I did score parking right in front, though.  (Thanks again, parking karma.)  I am really curious now to see how some gooey melted provolone would taste with the Korean steak.  Ahh, fuggit.  One more lunch hour won't hurt.  Thank you Yelp, for another great find.
author: Joe M.

description:
One mention of "Korean BBQ sandwich" and it had us sold. I think the sandwich was actually pretty considerable in size (and I'm a big eater!).  Maybe some people think that this is going to be the most massive sandwich ever (which is not true).  Or maybe people think that its going to come on a footlong bun.  Yet even though it is not the largest sandwich I've ever eaten, it is a pretty well-stacked, meaty sandwich.  We got so much bulgogi that it was "bulging" out of the bread.  The bulgogi's flavor was excellent.  Could have had more of the kimchi, but can't complain when you get that much meat.

On a sudden whim, I decided to have the Harrison St. pastrami sandwich instead of the 19th St.  I love pastrami.  While the sweet collision of pastrami, pepperoncini, spicy mustard, chipotle aioli gave me a burst of flavor, I could honestly say that it was good, but not great.  I found myself longing for the Korean BBQ sandwich or even the 19th St., which I will try next time I'm in town.  The good news is that I heard a new Rhea's Deli (with seating) is going to open very soon.

Overall, I would come here again, and recommend people to this place.  It has a total of five bar seats as it is situated in a convenience store, but well worth the 10 minute wait.   I would love to try the 18th or 19th St. burger.  And get a Korean BBQ sandwich to go while I'm at it!
author: Steve L.

description:
The Korean steak sandwich is worth the drive and totally worth the calories!

Rhea's is known for this sandwich for a good reason. It is overflowing with meat and dripping with flavor.
author: Seisha L.

description: Decided to give Rhea's Deli a try because a friend said he likes it better than Ike's. We picked up a Korean Steak Sandwich and Valencia Street and headed over to Dolores park to enjoy our food. I'll admit that the sandwiches were good, but they aren't the best I've had. The Korean Steak Sandwich tasted exactly how I expected to. Imagine bulgogi in sandwich bread. I personally don't think this combination goes well and found it very messy. The Valencia Street Sandwich was good, but the bread was a bit tough (the Korean Steak Sandwich's bread wasn't tough after being soaked by meat juices). The sandwiches are large, but pricey, and don't come with a bag of chips.
author: Christy K.

description:
Hm...I was rather disappointed by the place. It's been sitting in my queue forever and I finally got a chance to try it out. The place is an ordinary looking convenience store, but with a deli counter. I wanted the katsu sandwich, but they were out of it so I went with their most popular item, the korean steak sandwich. I wanted it spicy and with kimchi. 

Lo the behold, $11.84 later (and that's just for the sandwich, no chips or drinks), I got my sandwich. The kimchi came in a small condiment sized container instead of on the actual sandwich. The verdict? Well, there was plenty of meat, a bit of shredded iceberg, some cheddar and indistinguishable sauce (suppose to be chili garlic sauce and garlic aioli). There were also some pickled stuff in there, but it was hard to make it out.

My overall impression was that it was good, but not $11.84 good. I mean, if someone threw it in my direction, I wouldn't run the other way, but what they charge, especially considering it's the Mission, is pretty ridiculous. I don't mind paying $20 for a fois gras sandwich from Naked Lunch, but I just don't see the value of this place. Maybe they used great meat for the sandwich, but it certainly doesn't show. The meat was heavily marinated so I just tasted the sweetness of the meat and nothing else.
author: Alice W.

description:
Their sandwiches are, hands down, the best in the city. The main reason why is because I love how crunchy their Dutch Crunch is -- crunchy on the outside, but soft on the inside. I stopped going to Ike's after I discovered Rhea's. The Dutch Crunch over at Ike's turns soggy fast.

I took away one star because, on a couple of occasions, I waited much, much longer than what I was told the wait would be. I understand that they simply estimate how long it would take. But on the days I'm referring to, their estimates were WAY off. For example, I once waited 30 minutes longer than what I was told -- almost an hour total. But most times, I usually wait about 15-20 minutes for 2 sandwiches.

Overall, I think they make the best sandwiches in the city. Just give yourself time to wait because it's unpredictable how long it will take.
author: Kalea K.

description:
I've been to Rhea's 3 times now and I have admit they sure do live up to the hype of having thee best "Korean Steak sandwich". 

The bread is perfectly toasted...crunchy on the outside, soft in the inside. 
Bulgolgi is sweet and tender just as it should be. 
I normally get my sandwich at a medium spicy level, which is pretty spicy.
The add-ons (lettuce, jalepenos, pickled onions, regular onions, aioli, & I think sirracha) all compliment the sandwich very well. 

The gentleman at the counter was very friendly during my last visit which was on Sunday (7/29). Thanks for the great service! 

Overall, a great place to have lunch on a sunny day in the mission district.
author: Desiree B.

description:
The sandwiches are pretty good, each with distinct little flavors not found anywhere else...but is anyone else surprised that for a liquor store, the frequent flyers here are not as plastered as one would expect?!?!

1 star off: I placed an order over the phone and was told my sandwich would be ready in 40 minutes.  When I got there, I waited an additional 20 minutes (total 1 hour until my order was ready).  This is too long to wait for a sandwich, plastered or not.
author: Ally W.

description:
The Korean Steak sandwich is the BEST sandwich on earth! An amazing combination of distinct flavors all coexisting together and making for a delightful experience. The meat is super tender and the bread--sweet French roll--is perfect. 

In the words of a famous former governor: I'll be back!!!
author: sshawzam s.

description: Korean Beef and Katsu sandwiches are my favorite.
author: Yoichi N.

description:
Yum!! This place is amazing. I ordered the Korean steak sandwiches all around for the office I work at and we all loved it. 

I will order from here again and try something else next time.
author: Cel Y.

description:
Ambiance:  More than anything else, this is your typical California liquor store/deli market -- except for a few features.  One, there is an actual bar along the perimeter for sitting and eating.  I found this to be a very nice feature for those who were hoping to eat their sandwich right away while it was still hot.  Second, the place was pretty dang clean...  which, you know, is always nice.  No bathroom on site though; they have some sort of agreement with an establishment across the street, because they told us to go use their bathroom.  Ask them!

Service:  VERY nice people here.  Note:  If you're hoping for a quick in and out order and pickup, think again.  We came here on a Saturday and the wait for sandwiches was 45 minutes.  Being that the sandwich was the sole and singular purpose of our visit, we waited.  It was worth it.

Food:  We came for the Katsu Sandwich, but it has REGRETTABLY been discontinued. ARGH.  Oh well, we got the Korean Steak Sandwich. OMGAH.  It was to die for!  With kimchi and a good deal of flavor, the sandwich hit the spot.  We paired it with some cheap champagne (the lady working at the cash register told us which one was the best flavor for the cheapest price) and we waltzed on over to Dolores Park, eating and basking in the sun.  Twas bliss.

I marked down one star for the wait, because they changed their menu to get rid of the Katsu, and because of the lack of bathroom on site (none of which can be helped, but yea).  All in all, the service was good and the location was clean and pleasant. I'll be coming here for my badass-sandwich-fix again VERY soon.

4 out of 5!
author: Bryan H.

description: I am never coming back to this bad customer service place again they gave me regular sandwich with barely any meat in it yet on yelp the sandwiches have hella shit on it and she told me that those type of sandwiches are more expensive and then when I asked for more meat she's said its $3 extra if u had good customer service u would've said no problem let me take that for u I did not get my money worth the price I paid here I could've went to subway smh I don't recommend this boosie place to anyone !!!
author: Rashara M.

description: This place is so good. But they do dumb stuff like run out of food. They don't have any bread right now. What?! Get some bread then! Stop getting between me and my favorite sandwiches Rheas!
author: Matt L.

description: Got family ties to this spot. Dope everything. Evian water and werthers original are my go to's.
author: Yongjin C.

description:
Aaah... a hipster sandwich shop inside a corner store.  I'm surprised this trend isn't making headlines in the NYT.  Surely this is right up there with food trucks.  Luckily, where food trucks can be hit or miss, these sandwich shops are more of a sure thing.  I had both the Korean steak and Chicken Katsu here (split with someone else, not all by myself!).  They were both really yummy.  They were really big though so if I were just getting something for me, I could probably stretch out a sandwich into two meals.  They are also kinda messy to eat.  So definitely something to eat sitting down at home or somewhere where you can easily clean up or don't mind being a mess afterwards.  I do not recommend these sandwiches for hiking or a in-flight meal.

It's not clear the procedure when you get here so let me explain.  Pick up slips of paper to the immediate left of the door at the register.  Write down what you want, pay, then drop it off in the sandwich area.  It takes about 10 minutes to get your food.
author: Jean K.

description:
I was told hands-down I had to go to Rhea's and get a sandwich. The Market looks like a small 7-11 type convenience store, with a small deli counter and two guys furiously making sandwiches. 

Take a pad of order forms and a pencil, write your name and check off your order. Be careful though, because you'll check off a type of sandwich and it will be "discontinued," and you'll have to stand back in line and choose again. At peak times you may have to wait 30 minutes or more for your sandwich after you order. 

After being told twice that my sandwich order was not available, I ended up making my own creation a la carte. When I put in my order they had just announced that all sandwiches would be a 20-minute wait. I waited 40 minutes. I tried to wait as out of the way as I could, but inevitably was in everyone's way. 

The sandwich when I got it, was delicious and pretty large. A good portion for a $6-$9 sandwich. Call ahead if you don't have time to wait, that seems to be the best way to enjoy Rhea's.
author: Ana R.

description: Brisket was amazing, though I am not a fan of Russian dressing or slaw, it was very tasty with that amazing brisket, the pickles were snappy and flavorful, and the custom sodas hit the spot on a HOT day of walking all over SF (death march) , the raspberry soda was sweet, tart and super fizzy.
author: Robert C.

description:
I had the most incredible sandwich from here today that possibly was the best I had in my whole life. The Hemingway. 
Nuff said.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
Loved the spicy Korean, it wasn't burn your lips off hot but I had a nice lingering heat. My side of kimchee was a perfect addition. 

I loved the vibe, I loved the customer service, the doggy treats for Papas and friendly folks. 

One of my new haunts!
author: Jade W.

description:
My big bro asked me out for lunch today and he asked me if I was down for spicy food -- challenge accepted.  I'm never around this neighborhood enough to know what's around (although I know there are a lot of good places because i've driven by) so it was nice walking around on a beautiful day! Got the Korean BBQ sandwich and though it was a 20 minute+ wait... OH NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM! It was yummy! So funny because I didn't find the sandwich to be spicy, maybe a little but it wasn't as bad as he made it sound.  Definitely would come back here! So sad they only had one ginger ale can left and both of us wanted it :(  Obvi, I didn't get it but the pellegrino orange was pretty good :) 

Street parking all around so good luck!
author: Lisa L.

description: I love their grass fed meat sandwiches and kimchi included too! Higher quality deserves respect and repeat business.
author: Brian P.

description:
Finally got the chance to try the korean steak sammich spicy.  It was so d@mn flavorful, I'll overlook the drippy mess that exploded on my fingers.  I was so tempted to grab another one for my walk home.  Luckily, my friends were able to talk some sense into gluttonous me.

Until next time, KSS, I'll be seeing you in my dreams!

PS Be sure to call in your order ahead so you don't have to wait.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Honestly, the Veggie Steak Sandwich is the best sandwich I've ever had in my entire life. Not a weekend goes by where I don't think about heading to the mission to get one. Sometimes the lines can get a little crazy, but you can try to call ahead or get there right when the deli opens to decrease your wait time.

I wish I had a veggie steak sandwich right now. Le sigh. I might need an intervention.
author: Kaylie P.

description:
Ordered the Korean steak sandwich - it was ok - not worth 11.95 a piece - came out to over $26 for 2 sandwiches - meat was chewy and sinewy - onions were overpowering - bread and sauces were good, but the excess made the bread soggy pretty quickly.  Probably won't come back to try the other sandwiches - there's cheaper and better quality options out there (and probably more authentic) - but at least I gave it a try!

Not sure about the cleanliness behind the counter either...was a little turned off by lack of gloves worn.  But I'm a bit of a germ freak so to each his own.
author: Carissa S.

description:
+4 stars for *really tasty* sammiches. Like no kidding. Vegetarian BBQ Chicken featuring Layonna's famous vegetarian drum sticks. All you need to know. Carnivore sammiches rule as well. The God Father. Right on, in many ways.

+4 stars for really great service. Folks were helpful, polite, and eager to make really awesome sammiches. For. The. Win.

All that's subjective any way. What you need to know: HOME MADE KIMCHEE, BI7%#ES!
author: Mark S. I.

description:
I know I wasn't sure if I was in the right spot to try the sandwiches, but just fill out the slip and wait for the goodness. Wow that Korean steak sandwich is out of this world amazing. I have brought so many people here and they love it. The sandwich is just unique and an amazing combination. 

Thank you for whoever created this masterpiece.
author: Courtney P.

description: It's a popular place, but 20-30 minutes for a sandwich is a long wait. The sandwiches are good, but I think they're a bit pricy, and questionably worth the wait. There are less expensive options in the 'hood with the same quality, or better quality sandwiches for the same price. And without the attitude.
author: Cub C.

description: Some of the best deli sandwiches anywhere - prepared in a tiny kitchen in the back of a nondescript convenience store, and named after San Francisco streets. Fresh, tasty ingredients in really good bread. Hard to go wrong with the selection, but I recommend the 19th and the Korean steak.
author: Abdel H.

description: TIP: Call ahead to have sandwiches pre-made to pick up on the way to Dolores, especially on the weekend!  Or else, be prepared to wait between 15-45 minutes for these delicious sandwiches!  Very generous with fillings (no 2 slices of meat here), you can customize your order however you want.  They are a bit expensive if you get a specialty sandwich, but that usually yields two meals for me anyway.  The people who work there are so friendly even with the chaos on nice park days, mmmm!  Pick up some beer/chips/sandwiches and this is a one stop location for all :)
author: Raina D.

description: Best spot for sandwiches, the wait is pretty long during weekends so I suggest to call and make your order first. My favorite sandwich is the barney rubble. They even have a little space if you want to eat it there. Perfect lunch for a picnic at the park.
author: Suzy R.

description: Tried Rhea's for the first time the other day.  I had the 18st. sandwich and it was a good time.  The cashier was friendly and they offer a great assortment of sandwiches and drinks.  They also have a bar where you can sit and eat your meal - I think it seats up to maybe 7 or 8.  I enjoyed my experience and would return again.
author: Shaun W.

description: Excellent sandwiches: good meat, good bread, good fillings. Unexpected/original flavor combinations. I usually like to order my own at a deli, but I trust this place. No line like Ike's, and the sandwiches are just as good -- or even better. I've only had the Valencia St. but they all look delish. My new staple sandy stop.
author: Elena K.

description:
Call in to order or prepare to wait half an hour or more.

Great Korean steak sandwich. I'm Korean and I don't like fusion food but I'm saying that this is a good combination. Bulgogi meat combined with pickles(not pickle pickles, just slightly pickled onions, cabbage etc). Got it medium spicy. Really great combo, nice bread choice. Fairly drippy though.
author: Gee H.

description: Long overdue review. Delicious korean steak sandwich. I usually get mine medium spicy and without the cheddar. The wait can be long but you can call ahead. They also have vegetarian options! Get some it's it ice cream sandwiches for dessert :)
author: Michelle K.

description: So I rarely crave sandwiches, but Rhea's does some really good sandwiches.  I like the Korean bbq one the best, but the others that my wife has tried have all been really good too.  The store itself is also really clean, well organized, and counter service seems to always be pleasant.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I've walked by this corner market so many times and hadn't realized this was the deli dishing out the katsu sandwiches people rave about. A tad bit of a wait for food, but considering it was Pride weekend and gorgeous out, the benches outside were a nice place to people watch while you wait for your katsu to fry up. 

Acme roll, spicy aioli and some kind of cheery Asian-ish cole slaw. Definitely a perfect amount of bread for the filling and the whole thing is one of those contraptions where you just want more in your mouth. Messy little meal and I had aioli drops all over my shorts, but to quote, if it doesn't get all over the place...
author: Kevin L.

description:
i drool thinking about this place.
 its a liquor store/corner store
 BUT DONT BE FOOLED
 unconventional. fresh ingredients. large portions. unique ideas.
NOM. NOM. NOM. nomnomnomnomnom!!!!!!!!

 I love the guys behind the counter. 
be prepared to wait, they work hard, so tip them too!!!
author: Yesa T.

description:
I would recommend calling in orders - sometimes the wait is 30 minutes for a sandwich! Make sure you eat the sandwich promptly because it can get soggy.

Also, didn't like the cheese much - too gritty.... but I still love my Rhea's :)
author: Jess C.

description:
Repeated incompetence means a single star.

Twice in a row now I've had problems getting my sandwich after calling in advance, waiting the expected time, and then arriving and paying. If the sandwich isn't ready at the point you pay, you're stuck in a sort of limbo where it might sit on the to-go counter, but they'll never notify you until you ask. This afternoon it happened again and I think the guy who rung me up didn't even check the counter for my sandwich after I paid.

If you don't want your time wasted, skip Rhea's
author: Eric H.

description: Still the best thing going for sandwiches. Got "The Freak" today which is Pastrami,and  delicious Kimchi. Totally worth the lunchtime wait.The staff will keep you entertained with stories.
author: Lauren V.

description:
Reminds me a lot of the corner delis I love back in NY.

The dutch crunch bread is amazing, actually my favorite part of my veggie sandwich; I don't think I'll ever look at a sandwich the same way again.
author: Priscilla M.

description: I'd like to think of myself as a sandwich connoisseur, and Rhea's gets two thumbs up! The sandwiches are soo hearty and fresh, and I really like how they use the best ingredients to make them. My two favorite sandwiches are the Noe and the Dolores. The staff is also very nice and friendly, and it's always worth the wait. I can't wait to try ALL of their sandwiches.
author: Regina L.

description:
Great sandwiches to take up to doleres park. On a nice day expect a line. try the Korean steak sandwich- really yummy! Its full of meat on delicious fresh baked bread. 

I really like this place but in the end I think I like Ike's more. But this place wins when im at dolores park
author: Komal B.

description:
I'm in LOVE!!! This has got to be my favorite sandwich of all time. I love the Korean BBQ sandwich!! the pickled coleslaw and onions. The beef is super tender and juicy. Just thinking about it is making me want to order it for dinner. The bread is super yummy too.

I also got the pork katsu sandwich and it was also very good. But the KBBQ is definitely way better. Sooooo good! I want more!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Love their sandwiches, love their creativity, but .....  4 stars not 5 because somewhere along the line the customer service aspect is slipping.

In their effort to be all modern and 21st Century and computerized, they seem to have lost a little bit of the human touch.  This place is always crowded, always busy, so it makes sense to order via phone or internet, but be forewarned: you better know EXACTLY what you want, because the folks who answer the phone are not going to take the time to hold your hand and guide you.  

Case in point: two weeks ago, I ordered the Korean Steak Sandwich.  Yes, it was delicious, and yes, I'll admit, it is my responsibility to have read the menu completely, but I was surprised to find out that it came with CHEESE on it.  Cheese is one of those things that I expect the shop to say, "Would you like cheese with that?" or  "What KIND of cheese would you like on that?"  But, I didn't say anything about cheese, they sure as heck didn't ASK me anything about cheese, and lo and behold, my Korean Steak Sandwich arrives with American Cheese on it.  (Just in case you think I'm being a douche-bag here, I submit that it is pretty reasonable to assume that a Korean-style steak sandwich would NOT have cheese on it.  They don't really do cheese in Korea.  And, it's not called the Korean Cheese Steak sandwich, it's called Korean Steak sandwich.)

Okay, whatever, my bad, fine.  But then, today, I phone in an order for the Valencia, their totally awesome turkey-based sandwich.  Do I have their menu memorized?  No, I do not.  Does the guy answering the phone ask me if I want it Hot or Cold?  No, he does not.  Do I know that I'm supposed to specify that I want it Hot?  No, I do not.  So, what do I get?  A cold sandwich when I could've had a hot one.  Is there a big difference between hot, delicious MELTY cheese on your sandwich, and warm, delicious TOASTY bread versus cold slabs of solid cheese on room temperature bread?  COME ON!!  You know there's a big difference.  One is good, one is frickin' GREAT.  

So, again, sure, I'll take responsibility for making assumptions, but i think, at 8, 9, and 10 bucks a sandwich it's NOT unreasonable to expect that the person taking my order might use the following phrases:  "Would you like that HOT or COLD?"  "What kind of cheese would you like with that?"  I don't think that's asking too much, do you?  

Lessons learned:  1. assume cheese on every sandwich and specify which kind you want, otherwise expect boring American, even on a sandwich that doesn't need cheese at all (the Korean)  2. If you want it Hot, you better ask for it Hot, because the people answering the phone are apparently too busy to take the time to ask you.

Come on, Rhea's!  Don't just be really GOOD, but frickin' EXCELLENT.  Hold your customer service to the same high standard as your sandwiches and ingredients.    Thanks!!!
author: FoodDudeS F.

description:
Great sandwiches and an awesome beer selection, prices are reasonable.

Think Ike's but with NO LINE around the block.
author: Marc M.

description:
Ordered a fried chicken sandwich and sat at the bar while watching them make my food. 

Chef puts the bun down.
Carefully puts on one piece of chicken.
Two pieces.
Three.

...and then proceeds to go full Jackson Pollack with an avalanche of really, really good fried chicken on this poor little slice of bread. There were at least an entire clan of chickens piled onto this tower by the time he was done. It didn't fit on my plate. It didn't fit on any plate. And it was absolutely fantastic. 

Eat here. Eat here a lot.
author: Munaf A.

description: They jacked up the prices and no longer offer the katsu sandwich?! In this case the double negatives do NOT cancel each other out.
author: Justin C.

description:
Best sandwiches in all of SF! I love me some sammies but my one complaint is that most sandwiches don't have enough FLAVOR...after going to Rhea's Deli I will never have to complain of this again!! 

As a veggie their fake meat options are absolutely amazing (veggie BBQ chicken sandwich is killer), their unique ingredients all lend to one very amazing combination of flavors that makes my tongue dance just thinking about it! 

Another plus, the staff is usually super sweet, the wait time isn't bad, and the price is completely fair for what you're gettin. I highly recommend Rhea's!!!!!
author: Meagan Y.

description: + good hearty sandwiches
author: Margaret R.

description: This review is based solely on the Chicken Katsu sandwich!  #BestOfTheBay . Everything about this sandwich is perfect to me...great quality bread and toppings make this perfect piece of chicken katsu spectacular!!!
author: Mista N.

description: I planned to come here for the first time today to try the Vegetarian Bbq Chicken Sandwich.  However, as today went on I kept on getting tempted by other food options swimming through my head. At one point, I started talking myself  into going to Ike's or Taqueria Cancun instead.  Coming to my senses, I stuck with my original decision and was blown away.  At first, I was concerned it would just be a sandwich with fake meat slathered in barbeque sauce but after the first bite, I realized I was just being prejudiced.  In fact, looking back I am glad I had  such low expectations because the experience took me to a whole different level.  I have never gone to the same restaurant two days in a row but I'll promise you this, I'll be having another Vegetarian Bbq Chicken Sandwich tomorrow.
author: avi a.

description: OMG!!! The Korean Steak sandwich was awesome!! The bread was fresh and soft the rib eye was tender juicy with just the right amount to seasoning the chili garlic sauce and garlic aioli help but the sandwich over the edge.. Everything on the sandwich was fresh which is a plus!! It is a well put together sandwich!! Enough said!!!  The  next sandwich on the list for me,will be the Barney Rubble. I cant wait..;
author: Mae D.

description:
I'm being a bit generous with a 4 star rating here.  I made a special trip to rhea's to try the pork katsu sandwich. It was a half hour out of my way, but my brother said it was incredible - additionally, after seeing all the pics on yelp, I was sold.  Turns out they stopped making the katsu sandwich - the reason? It was too popular! WHAT?!?  Who stops producing their signature product for excess popularity? 

Anyways, I ended up having their other popular offering, which is the Korean steak sandwich.  Phenomenal - deserving of 5 stars.  I will go back for it many times I am quite sure.

They really need to get back on that Katsu - I still want to try it.
author: Tony B.

description:
Got the Korean steak sandwich. 
The bread was crusty on the outside and soft on the inside, and the steak was juicy and delicious! There was a lot of flavor going on, and it was tasty, but maybe a little much, and I wish the spice had some from the sauce instead of from the jalapenos, but overall it was really good, and I will definitely fo back and try something else!
author: Cami J.

description:
Oh dear lord, the Korean steak sandwich is quite possibly one of the best sandwiches I've ever had!

A bit pricey at $10.35, and not exactly huge portion-wise, but it's just so damn juicy and good.
author: David W.

description: My Korean steak sandwich was good but the sauce was a bit too sweet for my taste.  However, my dining partner's katsu sandwich was disappointing. The katsu was so dry. It also looked like it was deep fried and set to sit under the heat lamp for days!
author: LeTran B.

description:
Oh, the sammiches. I work directly across the street from Rhea's, which has turned out to be a nightmare as all I ever want to eat is the tasty chicken katsu sandwich.

I would definitely recommend coming here for lunch. Take your sandwiches and a drink over a couple blocks to Dolores park and enjoy the pretty sights of San Francisco (if it's not raining, of course).
author: Tim J.

description:
The place itself is kinda small, so it can get a little cramped when ordering or waiting for your order. That's it. That's the only critique I have of this place.

The sandwiches use excellent ingredients, so on top of tasting really fresh, the flavors and textures of their sandwiches really deliver.

One of the especially nice things is that if you order a sandwich that isn't too saucy, it holds up exceptionally well if you want to buy a sandwich and save it for later. I ordered a 19th St. sandwich for lunch but didn't eat it until later for some midnight munchies. It STILL tasted great and the bread was not soggy at all.

One of the better sandwich places I've tried. I would go again and again.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Tried the 19th Street + it was delish! Crunchy sweet bread meets succulent slices of roast beef coupled w/ fresh veggies + flavorful garlic sauce. Yummm!

Then again, for $9.80 it should be tasty or I'd be quite disappointed.

Service was ok...the staff seemed more interested in chatting their friends up than trying to get me out of there.
author: Julie L.

description:
The korean steak sandwich here renewed my appreciation for being a carnivore. yes, mmm... juicy, delicious, flavorful meat.. I usually don't eat that much red meat, but for Rhea's korean steak sandwich, its a different story and i'll be more than happy to make that exception any day. 

a quick story: the other day I went for the sandwich but they'd ran out of acme rolls and couldn't make the steak sandwiches, only the "drier" normal ones on regular bread -sad and disappointed like a 5 year old, I mulled over the menu as I attempted to find another acceptable substitute for what I came in with my heart (or should I say stomach?) set on. but THEN! there was hope.. they'd got more soft rolls in..! not acme, but still, GOOD ENOUGH. and off he goes with making my sandwich! rode home in a hurry with it, dropped all my things down, and unwrapped the goodness that was the korean steak sandwich from Rhea's.

I wish this was my corner store. I'm only a 5 minute bike ride away... but still. come here for the sandwich, the kimchee, and the really awesome and nice people working here.
author: Jennie L.

description:
Rhea's looks unassuming enough but inside this Korean owned convenience store, you'll find the best Korean sandwiches in town.  

The hefty Korean steak sandwich ($7.95) is a lovingly layered masterpiece starting at the bottom with a lovely, lightly toasted, chewy organic Acme sweet roll (like ciabatta), followed by garlic aioli, a layer of hot sauce (you can specify how spicy you'd like your sandwich), thick slices of cheddar cheese, a bold, juicy, beefy layer of thin marinated ribeye, pickled, grilled and fresh onions, crunchy vinegary pickled jalapenos and shredded iceberg lettuce. It's a flavor and texture explosion of the best kind.  Minor areas for improvement: the cheese was soft but not melted, the beef wasn't warm and I wonder how it would taste with some kim chi.

I noticed after I ordered my sandwich that they have Korean steak tacos, 2 for $6.  Yum.  You can also get other sandwiches on Acme bread (good bread makes a difference).  Standard deli sandwiches with Boar's Head deli meat are $5.

The inside is your typical convenience store only cleaner and nicer.  They have a counter if you want to eat your sandwich there.  They carry what 7-Eleven does (milk, cheese, ice cream, cereal, cookies, candy, juice, wine) but they also have gourmet cheeses, Cowgirl Creamery crackers and jars of homemade kim chi (made by the Korean guy's mom).

Bookmark this place.  You won't regret it.
author: Lolia S.

description: Go in around 3pm on a sat.  There was no line but wait about 15 min for the pastrami Sammy.  Yummy! Big sammy and really this is the best in SF.  Great bread and sauce; the lettuce is so fresh.  What can I say, go try it if you haven't have one before. Prepare to put down $10.
author: Lantz G.

description: they sold me rancid and expired "egyptian dish" baba ghanosh. i want my money back. do not sell poison food and steal my money assholes.
author: Pete S.

description: Never ordered from them before today. I asked for only meat, cheese and pickled onions on my sandwich. They put everything on it, which means it's inedible to me. I hate mayo, lettuce and spicy things and now I have a sandwich full of all of those nasty things. Who needs lunch? Oh wait. I still do. I will not be back.
author: Shani H.

description: Korean steak sandwich all the way.  Warm on a crusty sandwich roll.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Heard about Rhea's and we were in the neighborhood.  Found a parking space which is a feat in itself!!!  Got to Rhea's around 11:10 am on a Saturday.  Was surprised that there was no line.  A guy told us that sandwiches weren't available for 20 minutes, so we thought the deli wasn't opened yet and decided to walk around and come back at 11:35am.  When we arrived a girl told us that if we ordered sandwiches now it won't be ready until 12:15pm or so and walk around and come back.  They received a lot of call-in orders and our order would be next in line.  They won't stop and make sandwiches for walk-ins.

I said we already walked around and waited over 30 minutes to place our order.  The guy earlier didn't tell us that we could place our order then and come back.  We weren't going to wait another 30+ minutes for a sandwich!!!  She did ask who the guy was but he wasn't there to point him out and she did apologize.

So beware, call your order in first because if there's a lot of call-in orders, you'll have to wait... might as wait at home or use the time to drive and find parking!!!!

We went to Lou's Sandwiches on Geary Blvd.
author: M. K.

description:
This place was on Check Please Bay Area on KQED. I watched it with my mom.
Since then, I have been twice. Got the Korean BBQ sandwich both times.
Semi long wait- about 10 minutes. Totally worth it. Grab a beer, since it is a liquor store, sit down and enjoy.

Not sure if you are allowed to drink in the store, but we did... we sat in the corner.

Sandwiches are pricey- about 7 bucks I think. But big and delicious.
author: Genevieve E.

description: Sandwiches are delicious. I tried the chicken BBQ and Valencia Street, both toasted (VS wins, but barely). I could eat here everyday.  What I can't do is wait in the ridiculous line, so I avoid it on the weekends. Only a few spots to sit, so best to get it to go.
author: Janelle F.

description:
Excellent sandwiches! I tried both the korean steak sandwich and the katsu sandwich, and to my surprise preferred the katsu. Both had a nice spicy kick to them without having other flavors overwhelmed. I thought the katsu came together better with a great crunch from the pork and the slaw. It was also better constructed and held together well. I don't like red onions so we got them on the side of the steak sandwich, and I have to admit it was better with onions (which were pickled, so I do prefer those to raw red onions). I'd also requested it without the cheese, because that just seemed like too much, but I have to say that I do now have a lot of faith in their sandwich ideals, so in the future I'd probably go with every topping they recommend.

Next time I would ask for them to go a bit lighter on the aioli - it's good, but a little goes a long way. I'd look forward to having the katsu again or trying their other sandwiches!
author: Lisa K.

description: Like your neighborhood deli, but the sandwiches are more hip, e.g., Korean Steak Sandwich, Turkey with Sriracha and Cranberry Sauce (The Dolores).
author: James G.

description: Had the "18th st". Takes a while but well worth the wait, delicious!
author: Sindre P.

description:
I see some consistencies in the negative reviews, and they all seem to revolve around poor customer service.  I think the problem might be that the place is staffed by idiots, stoners, or idiot-stoners.  

It's a deli, I know there are a lot of choices, but come on, it's not that hard.  But, apparently, for Rhea's, it is.   Woe onto the person who dares stray from the established menu to get a variation on the "named" sandwiches.  Perhaps you're like me, perhaps you feel mustard has no place on a turkey sandwich, or pepperoncini for that matter, but you like everything else on that "Hemingway."  Good luck getting that level of "customization" to your order from the brain trust that works there.

Plus, with everyone complaining about the wait time, you would think calling your order in would be to your advantage.  Nope.  Try again.  

Jeez, folks.  I feel you, we're in Northern California, we're all so G-ddamn laid back, but can you put just a little bit of effort into customer service?  Can you take some frickin' pride in serving FOOD to people?  'Cause the level y'all are operating at, you should be like MAYBE stocking shelves at Target, but definitely NOT producing anything that I'm going to consume and digest.  

Either that, or pass the joint to everyone waiting to get served, don't just keep it for yourselves behind the counter.
author: Invisible J.

description: Really great sandwiches.  I generally order the Ms Piggy but no one I know has been disappointed so far.  Great menu with vegetarian options.
author: Allison Z.

description:
We came here on Sunday around noon and ordered two sandwiches, the Korean Steak and The Freak.  The cashier told us it was about a 15min wait.  (It was shorter, which was nice!)  We took the sandwiches home to eat.  Here's what I thought:

The Korean Steak (medium spicy)- Flavors were really good.  Totally didn't expect cheddar to work with Korean marinated beef, but it really does! Also nice they really don't skimp on the beef.  I'd order it again.

The Freak-Pastrami and kimchi seemed like a pretty strange combo but I thought it worked together fine.  The pastrami was pretty good and plentiful.  There wasn't that much kimchi and the kimchi was more sour than spicy but it seemed to work well in the sandwich.  It seemed a little sweeter than I liked.  I actually couldn't figure out why...maybe the bread?  Some sauce? Not bad, and pretty interesting but I might try something else next time.

I like the flavors so I'd come back, but I think next time I might eat there or close by since the sandwiches were a little soggy because I brought them home.
author: Tabitha S.

description:
Rhea's. Lovely. Rhea's is great because they not only make incredibly delicious sandwiches, but they also deliver them. The minimum for delivery is only $10, and it's easy to make up an even 10 if you add on a candy bar or a can of soda.

And the sandwiches - oh the sandwiches. Perfect bread, great combinations, delightfully local names, amazing ingredients. Who puts havarti next to tomato and avocado on a turkey sandwich? I do. And so does Rhea. And that's amazing.

So, go there.

And if delivery of one sandwich, and each sandwich being excellent, aren't enough for you... I invite you to open your mind to the possibilities of a liquor and sandwich store with a delivery system. They deliver sandwiches! They deliver candybars! And yes.... well, you devise the rest.
author: Megan G.

description:
Went today and ordered two korean steak sandwiches. Luckily we called in the order since 30 mins was the quoted wait. We got there in 20 mins and our sandwiches were ready. FYI when you order sandwiches by phone, you go to the cashier to check for your order.

The korean sandwich is so yummy and on par to Ike's. Personally I prefer Rhea since it's not as saucy as Ike's (aka messy to eat). The korean steak has a spicy sauce and jalapeños for an extra kick. Ask for mild if you can't handle spicy food like me. The beef is perfectly marinated, not dry, and the sauce pulls it all together. Def recommend you try. Next on my list is the Katsu sandwich.
author: Jenny G.

description: I think my review would be different if I hadn't waited several years to get to Rhea's.  I've been hearing about this Korean Steak Sandwich for a while and I ignored all other options when I placed my order.  I was concerned about spice and went for mild, which I think was a mistake as there was no heat at all.  I took the sandwich not far to Dolores Park and the top of the bread got a little soggy, which wasn't ideal, but wasn't necessarily devastating either.  All in all, it was a solid sandwich.  It just wasn't spectacular.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Great deli...hipster central. The sandwiches are great... can't complain about that. The only knock is that the sandwiches are about $10 (average deli sized) and the wait is about 20 min. 

I walk away thinking....$10 and 20 min wait for a sandwich? it's a damn good sandwich....but worth it? close call.
author: W R.

description:
Long mother-effing wait
Heavy weight on the palette. 
No seat? Dolores
author: Steven C.

description:
how lucky was I to be convinced by such a charming staff of my fortunate luck to get the last piece of day old bread for my Korean Steak Sandwich -- so lucky to have incurred a $1.00 upcharge, making my sandwich $10.95. I knew I should have worn tighter gear and mascara.

it doesn't seem right for me to say they left a bad taste in my mouth since the sandwich was pretty tasty, cheese and all - but it may be a cotton-pickin minute before I find myself there again.  i was really there to find the Friday Pie Lady anyway ;P
author: eVa J.

description: 'The Valencia' is the best plain-jane deli style sandwich I've ever had, plain and simple.
author: Joe D.

description:
Wow...I never thought I'd Yelp again after the busiest month of my entire career. But I made it back and I'm happy to put in a sparkling review for Rhea's Deli, as the first of many catch up reviews for Yelp!

Went here because we saw a show with the Pork Katsu sandwich show. Found out it was a very old rerun, so went with the Korean Beef sandwich. Ordered one mild and it still slapped my taste buds in the mouth with spice but there was so much flavor than the little hot kick.

The small staff was crazy cool and laid back but it is in the Mission, so kinda expected. 


Can't say that after tasting it, I'm in "gotta have it" mode. More like if I'm in the area and want a good sandwich, Rhea's is the place to go.
author: Troy R.

description:
Dear Rhea's,

I was originally quick to pass judgement on your deli because of the drab outside look of your establishment and should have known based on my love of the Mission in general that you would be nothing but awesome.  I'm pleased that my husband insisted that I join him in eating a delicious Korean steak sandwich made so lovingly and was packed full of flavor.

Consider me sold on your greatness.  I will be back, to sample your entire sandwich board.

Love, 
Me
author: Margaret I.

description:
The korean steak sandwich is a great combination of delicious korean steak and cabbage, and the spicy is just spicy enough to give you a kick without being too painful to the palate. 

The only issue is they no longer do the Katsu sandwich :(
author: Rohan D.

description: I am so happy I can get a vegan sandwich in the mission! And a f**king good one at that. Haha! I went here for the first time today for lunch, and even though I had to wait 20 minutes, it was totally worth it. I ordered the BBQ Veg Chicken Sandwich, and it was BOMB. Come here if you don't mind waiting!
author: Jenn K.

description:
great sandwiches, great bread, cool staff. The sandwich is wrapped tight so that all your ingredients stay together, not falling out all over the place, and the bread is never soggy. so much better than ike's. 

When I'm carnivorous I like the Dolores St. 
When I'm vegetarian: Miss Piggy FTW. omfgggggg. so. good.
author: AA B.

description:
Neighborhood market meats Spicy Asian Sandwiches. Awesome.

They're big sandwiches, guys. I'm 6'2" and I only really need half a sandwich.
author: Ben M.

description:
Really nice guys working here

Ordered a spicy steak sandwich 'to go' for the hubby. 20 minute wait, no problem because benches outside to sit and wait.

It's a huge sandwich!
author: Foodlover B.

description: My husband kept bugging me to try this place with him so I consented. I'm not much of a sandwich person but I do crave for it once in a while. He ordered the Korean Steak sandwich and I tried it too. It was actually good and he enjoyed it very much. The sandwich had a lot of meat. I like how they also sell a lot of craft beer too in their market and other stuff. I only gave it four stars because we had to wait 20 minutes for it! We might try to come back to check out their other sandwiches.
author: Cindy S.

description:
Korean bbq OMG!  Every other sandwich OMG!   Prices are a bit OMG as well, but hey, this is SF.  You pay for what you get. 

Call ahead.   Save yourself the time in line.
author: Adrian M.

description:
Our office called in to order 7 sandwiches and we were told that they couldn't make 7 sandwiches. WTF?

The guy's name was George. Was kind of a dick on the phone.
author: Christopher U.

description:
tried the sandwiches today per Yelp's favorite reviews.

I ordered a custom one with pastrami and smoked ham hot.  Taste just so so.  Nothing to write home about.    I didn't get the chance to try the Korean bbq one since is was out.  Maybe that worth the trip.  

seem to me it is a bit overhyped.
author: Abe T.

description: I love being able to enjoy a great sandwich and a beer inside a liquor store.  Watching all the people walking by outside oblivious to the deliciousness within.  Korean steak sandwich is gods gift to my mouth.  Veggie options are also great.   Bonus- they have 4 kinds of it's- its available.
author: Melissa H.

description:
YUM. A small convenience store paired with an unassuming deli on the side that serves up huge sandwiches piled high with deliciousness. Also available is their homemade kimchi that comes in mason jars. 

The Katsu (pork or chicken both available) sandwich is a crunchy, meaty, beauty of a mess layered in between beds of fresh, colorful slaw and enveloped in a deliciously chewy crackly soft Acme roll. The Korean steak is also a winner - tender, flavorful bulgolgi piled high with kimchi and cheddar and also comes in an Acme roll. You can choose your level of spice - and spicy definitely has a delicious kick to it.

Definitely call your order in ahead of time (30-40 minutes on a weekend, when you're definitely not going to be the only one with the brilliant idea to nurse your hangover at Rhea's). 

Also, ~$8-9 for a sandwich? JESUS. Luckily though, it's kinda worth it.
author: Betty W.

description:
Like some of the other reviewers, I saw Rhea's on that PBS show, Check Please, Bay Area. All of the reviewers on the show loved it, but I was still somewhat skeptical. A liquor store deli? Really? How good can a sandwich really be? 

I finally tried this place out last weekend. Simply put, I had one of the best sandwiches I've ever had in my life. Oh the bread, and the garlic aioli, and the quality of ingredients. Sooo good!!!! I had the Valencia, a taste of the Korean steak (quality steak, perfect spiciness, and amazing fresh slaw) and my new friend at the counter (it's cozy in there) was raving about his veggie chicken sammie. The combos sound a little odd, but they just work, so go for one of their creations. 

Yes, it is in a liquor store, but it's very clean, and run by a super friendly staff. Eat at the counter (awesome people watching), sit on the benches outside, or grab it to go and head over to Dolores park (more awesome people watching). Try this place out, you won't regret it!!
author: Joy P.

description: Does not disappoint. The short girl in there is friendly and helpful and fast. The sandwiches are great.  If you are looking to have a better than average sandwich try this spot.  I had the one with pesto. I look forward to being in that area of town again just to get a sandwich.  Two other guys were with me and they were equally impressed.
author: Aric W.

description: Absolutely amazing sandwich. Found this gem on Yelp and it was perfection. My friend and I ordered two to go and headed to Dolores Park to picnic. Dutch crunch was to die for. Best of all they have cute little order sheets where you can customize your own sandwich if you're overwhelmed with all the options (like I tend to get). haha. Will definitely be back!
author: Naseem K.

description:
Pretty good Korean steak sandwich, although I think translating Korean fusion into a burrito is tastier.

It was nice and spicy, but was I left with a weird flavor with the piece of American cheese interspersed in the Korean steak sandwich. Bread (rumored to be Acme) was a nice touch. 

At $9+ it felt a bit spendy.
author: Lee H.

description:
Their complete unpretentiousness (for their level of deliciousness) is refreshing.

Has this place ever been on scanwiches.com? Probably not, cuz the sheer awesomeness of their sandwiches would BREAK THE MACHINE.

The chicken/pork katsu sandie is my favorite. That slaw is so fresh and crunchy. The spicy/sweet mayo is wonderfully unctuous on the tongue after all the pleasantly gritty panko, as a first year art student would scream: JUXTAPOSITION! I forget which bread we had it on but it was fresh and crusty. Yum.

Yesterday I got the Han Solo (zucchini, avocado, greens, some yummy cheese, and garlic aioli) but couldn't finish, the other half is our fridge right now and I'll probably eat it after I write this review.

Here's what you do, go into the deli, pick up a sandwich order form, fill it out, and then wait for your name to be called.

The sandwiches are a perfect size, too--- generous but not overstuffed. Very balanced. 

Also, the other day my fiance saw A-1 (the rapper) eating there. So cool, rappers eat sandwiches too.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
If you are in a hurry you may want to consider the many nearby option...but that said the Korean sandwich was GREAT!!!!  Great location close to Dolores Park and everything Mission!
Not sure if the 40 minute wait for our sandwiches is normal/typical or this was just an off day.  They were apologetic and the end result was a GREAT sandwich and some great people watching! 
Oh ya, and they have a fair selection of craft brews in bottles as well as all kinds of snacks and sundry items.
CHEERS!
author: Sean M.

description:
None of the sandwiches were there that we wanted, and I'm not talking about what had sold out.  There wasn't a single breaded chicken sandwich in the place!  Then after we place the order and pay we were told it was a 30 minute wait, wish they would have told us before hand.

The staff was very friendly, the beverage and chocolate/candy selection is  great, however, the Boars Head turkey sandwich I got was good but not worth the wait.  I wanted what they were known for and it wasn't sold out, there was some other "in between kitchens" thing we were told.  

Wish we made the trip in the heat for a good reason not a typical Boars Head deli hero that took 30 minutes to make.   Seriously people that kind of sandwich is sold everywhere and made in 5 minutes.  

The steak sandwich was good, but again, not worth the wait.  Perhaps next time.  Also, on a hot day PLEASE open the windows, if they do open so people can eat with some air.
author: B K.

description:
Rhea's, my corner store, is one of the many factors that has led to my completely spoiled, pampered existence here in the city.

Firstly, the sandwiches are a force to be reckoned with; somehow they are prepped with more delicious ingredients then you might shake a stick at (whatever that means) such as garlic or horseradish aioli and fresh (grilled if you like) bread and avocado (this is the mission!). And where else might you go for an amazing deli sandwich late into the evening?

Secondly, the deli cheeses I've tried were great, same with the wine and beer selection. 

Lastly, the guys here seem cool, like they actually enjoy themselves or something crazy like that. They've probably reached sandwich nirvana.
author: Alan F.

description: I walked into Rhea's today at a total loss. I asked the bearded gentleman behind the counter what should I possibly order? He asked me about my dietary restrictions and hobbies, ultimately deciding my best option would be to go with the Korean steak. I trusted him, and I'm sure glad I did. Bless the gentleman with the beard!
author: Brandon D.

description:
The sandwiches are NUTS. Everything is garlic-y. Everything is delicious. Produce is fresh, and there's no skimping on cheese or meats.  They have a lot of great combinations already picked out, and they don't care if you want to modify the hell out of them. Or you can just design your own sandwich. Their menu is online, most of the sandwiches run $7-9. Pretty standard for Valencia.

I don't know why it takes so long for the sandwiches. A 25 minute wait during lunchtime is not uncommon, nor is it understandable. Any fastfood sandwich place can pump out a sandwich in a under 5 minutes. The quality here is a lot better, but the basics of sandwich-making are the same.

Just call your order in ahead of time and avoid waiting outside for 20-30 minutes.
author: jared c.

description: Dude. The vegetarian (vegan if you skip the aioli) BBQ "Chicken wing" sandwich is the shit. Better than any vegan option at Ike's. There. I said it. I am HOOKED! And the kimchee...oh, my! Super cheap and walking distance from my house too. I win!
author: Susie D.

description:
If you go here, get the Korean Steak Sandwich (or don't, they have a bunch of other great sandwiches). I'll be going back here to try some of the other sandwiches listed, but I was pretty impressed with the Korean Steak they had. 

It was a lovely sandwich and I let it sit in the bag for a bit before eating it. Let those juices soak up into the bread and you're in for a treat :)

Pricing was nice, and they have a great selection of kettle chips along with standard tall boys/sodas. Nice little bench outside to sit and eat/mingle when the day is rain free :)

Great little spot on the corner, but I forget the hours sometimes and end up craving a sandwich at 6pm only to forget they close the sandwich shop at 5 M-Th :(
author: Nick E.

description: Finally I managed to be there on-time once to get their famous Korean Steak sandwich. Every single previous try, I dealt with a sold out sign on that item. It was really tasty with a nice kick of spice, I would say great quality per price. It is a supermarket, so you should not expect an ambiance or service there, but a great stop for a snack if you in the Valencia area in SF.
author: Sasan A.

description: I think the owner was nervous because who ordered Korean barbecue was Korean... lol. Food was so good like it's straight out of Seoul. Bread was bit hard tho.
author: Ilhoon J.

description:
Yes, I finally made it to Rhea's. Since I live in the Outer Richmond, going to the Mission requires some planning on my part. I went at 11:30 AM, metered parking was easily available across the street, and I was the first to order when the Deli opened. 
I had already decided on the Korean but once I saw the sandwich menu on the board, I knew I had to come back and try the rest. The Sandwich was ready in less than 10 minutes and I could wait to get home and try it, along with the homemade kimchi that they sell. The sandwich was as spicy as I requested and the meat was just super tender. The size is huge. I could only eat half for lunch. Saving the other half for later! Since is a market, they carry  decent selection of wines and beer. 
I will be back!
author: Frank B.

description:
Church sandwich or veggie BBQ chicken are absolutely amazing.  One of the best sandwiches ever. I am glad I wandered in here randomly looking for lunch.  Google said it was the closest sandwich to my location, it was like 12 feet away from where I was.

I was not expecting that sandwich to be that good.  I am tempted to try the other fake meat sandwiches they have now.  If they stocked Newcastle 22oz I would be in heaven.  Although they do have Rouge Brown Hazelnut and hella other drinks to go with my sandwich time.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I've said it before and I'll say it again...I LOVE SANDWICHES! And wow, Rhea's Deli makes some damn good ones!

My boyfriend & I ended up ordering the Korean BBQ Beef & Katsu Sandwiches (Medium Spicy for both) to go so we could eat it at SFO before our flight back home. I was a bit skeptical if the sandwiches would still be good a couple hours later but yup, Rhea's proved me wrong and was still mighty delish!
