I absolutely loved the sauces on both sandwiches (hello garlic aioli & tonkatsu sauce!) and the ACME Bread was chewy, crunchy & held everything together nicely. Both were equally amazing, but if I HAD to choose, I would prefer the Katsu Sandwich (only because I'm a sucker for spicy mayo). 

The guys working the deli were awesome! Super friendly and easy to talk to. Oh yeah, it also didn't hurt that we didn't encounter a line during our visit ;) While Rhea's may be a bit more $$ than Ike's, I would still highly recommend it. Seriously...Japanese & Korean inspired sandwiches? They nailed it!

FYI, Rhea's Deli is located in a legit liquor store/market. I kind of liked how you could just order some sandwiches & pick up a couple of drinks/chips and pay for it all together. Just make sure to fill out the little paper next to the cashier to place your order ;)
author: Faye G.

description: Is this a 40 minute sandwich?  Yup.  I think this is actually better than Ike's...less selection, but the flavors here just deliver.  That vege bbq chicken is ridic...the slaw on there is amazing...slaw people, I'm talking about friggin slaw.   Oh yeah, call ahead.
author: A A.

description:
I'm hesitant to rate because I know it will only lead to longer lines but Rhea's is too good to not give credit.  

The Harrison is my joint.  All day everyday.  Makes me happy every time.  Far superior to those soggy sandwiches that all taste alike over at Ike's.
author: Domad N.

description: Walked into this incredible store and was greeted by a very nice man with a beard. He showed the sandwich collection and clearly explained my options. I got my sandwich within 10 minutes (very fast!) and it was delivered by the guy with the beard again! He was awesome! Go beard guy!
author: Daryl H.

description:
excellent fried chicken and burger with blue. came back twice.

katsu was meh.

waitress was slightly lost but confessed she was new. 

no refills on fountain drinks.
author: Brandon N.

description:
The price is right. The food is tight. [...crap I'm about to say blah, blah, take a massive bite] anyway-

Look:
Order the Katsu. Order the Valencia Street. Order the Korean steak (spicy). YUM. 

Pro-tip, call ahead. Take 20 minutes.  worth it. so worth it. 

(look away from the kettle chips when you first walk in. seriously, you don't need those damn chips -- but if you really do, get the salt/vinegar. perfect)
author: Trinity M.

description:
I HAVE SEEN THE LIGHT-at Rhea's in the form of  their BBQ Korean steak sandwich done spicy and YES,LORD IT WAS GOOD.
AMEN
author: Antoinette S.

description:
Went here based on the CHECK PLEASE show. How else would I find it?!? Seems this place has been afforded not only one running but a few re-runs as well. Good for them.
I did not read any Yelp reviews before going, so I was not sure what to expect and ordered what sounded good to me. I did order the Korean Beef Sandwich. Must say, it was really super in all regards. If you whine about the price, split a sandwich, get a bag of chips and a drink and be happy. Or go get a slice of pizza or a Safeway sandwich - whatever floats your boat. 
I'd go back (from Palo Alto) and certainly understand the Chicken Katsu debate - does not make sense to me but whatever. I worked at a kitchen where Kim-Chi was made in-house. Be grateful they keep theirs in a jar and behind the counter. It can overwhelm a place really fast. I can still smell it after being gone for 10 years.

I didn't mind waiting :20 for the sandwich - at least they were honest and it took a full :20. Does not seem like a place to order office sandwiches - just a bit time consuming for that I might think. Did see two bike messengers come through - they had to wait for their pick-up orders as well. Everyone worked at a nice pace - no big rush. They are looking to hire someone - probably get free lunch also!

If you think about the alternatives to a $9 sandwich being a bottle of booze, choose the sandwich.
author: Tom S.

description:
There are some meat-filled food items that cause me to pity vegetarians and vegans...The Dolores and The Godfather are two such glorious examples.

Standards and ethics/whatever aside, it's meaty sandwiches like these two that make me realize the other half of San Francisco doesn't know what they are missing. OMG I fantasize about the sandwiches from Rhea's. Seriously, they are tasty.

The dutch crunch roll that houses the amazing ingredients of The Dolores is a major reason why I keep ordering that sandwich...that and everything else about it is delicious. The Godfather is amazing 'cause of ALL THE MEAT. Seriously...lots of Italian meat. I couldn't even finish it the last time and surrendered it to someone else....then watched regretfully as they ate the last 1/4 of it. Never again will I drink beer and eat a sandwich from Rheas, must save room in stomach for only sandwiches!! Another standout is The Reuben; yeah, it looks smaller than the others (since its not on a roll) but the sandwich-maker-gods jam pack it with deliciousness.

You get a lot of sandwich for the price, too. Which is great and has made me a loyal sandwich customer. I really don't consider eating sandwiches at other deli's 'cause I know that I'll get a lot of food for my money, and it's top quality ingredients.

The only thing that saddens me is how busy they get. I've waited about 40mins for my sandwich...spent most of the time staring longingly at the deli counter. On the plus side, the cashiers are funny and friendly. There's also the Phoenix bar across the way, so you could kill some time drinking.

Rhea's deli is just another reason why living in the Mission is awesome. Hmmm, I'm hungry now :(
author: Amanda C.

description: About 15 minutes ago I stopped in Rhea's for a sandwich and had a horrific experience.  I walked up to the counter to fill out the sandwich order form and there was a homeless person wandering in and out of the store yelling some gibberish while being ignored by the staff.  As I'm filling out the form, the homeless man decides to throw some sort of dirty wrapper/paper on me.  I yell at him and he decides to square up and start yelling back.  The staff is practically ignoring him when he spits all over my face.  One of the employees finally escorted him out while laughing and implied it was my fault.  I look around to the rest of the staff and especially the lady who I've seen there every single time I've ordered a sandwich and waited for some sort of acknowledgement, but they continued on as if nothing happened.  I stormed out looking to call the police on the man, but he was gone and the employees couldn't care less.  I wasn't looking for a free sandwich, but just some acknowledgement and empathy over what happened.  I'm done with this place.  This is the one time I would prefer someone replacing a business on valencia st with more condos.
author: Jesse M.

description:
As if Rhea's didn't have tons of reviews already....but DAAAAAAAAAAYUUUUUM the Korean Steak Sandwich deserves all the acclaimed praise!  It's delicious. Let me repeat that again with a little more emphasis, IT IS DELICIOUS. The beef is nicely flavored with honey, soy sauce and other spices. The grilled onions have a slight tangy, almost lemon like flavor to it. The garlic aoli compliments the kimchee and chili spread quite nicely. Pair this a 40z and you're all set. 


...Ike's, watch out. You've got a strong contender.
author: May D.

description: The Veg BBQ Chicken, one of the 10 best Vegetarian sandwiches I have had the pleasure of enjoying.  An instant favorite. I will be back. Price was 8.95, not the cheapest...but worth it and comparable to similar SF sandwiches of this caliber.
author: John H.

description:
This is for the Kimchee....tastes like my ancient family recipe, if I was korean and if I had any korean relatives that make kimchee in a bathtub in the backyard.  But, I have tried other ancient family recipes from my korean friends and this stuff is homemade goodness.  

I have to stop being that beggar friend when grandma drops off her kimchee to her grandchildren.  So to Rhea's I go.  It's the closest I will get to having grandma's kimchee.
author: Miss H.

description: Got the Korean bbq sandwich. It is piled with meat that is sweet and tender. Wish there was more of smoky, grilled flavor. The sauces make the sandwich that much more yummier and slightly messy. The hint of kick from the jalpenos and chili garlic sauce is a nice counter flavor to the sweetness of the meat. The onions add a nice crunch to the sandwich. The acme roll is also key because the crunch from the outside of the bread with the soft inside just makes this sandwich that much more yummy. It's looks small but it is packed with flavor and you will be full.
author: Eve C.

description: Good options for sandwiches and the Dolores on the Dutch crunch turned out being a fresh choice. Only issue was the somewhat long (15 min) turnaround when there were no other customers..
author: Vatche A.

description:
I haven't reviewed Rhea's yet?  All I can really say is that the sandwiches are AMAZING!  I am keeping this one short so you can get off your duff and get one NOW! 

(and to be honest, i am a pretty crappy writer)
author: Adrian L.

description: Went here for a late lunch and was surprised to find a little deli counter inside an otherwise unremarkable convenience store. The Korean steak sandwich here is surreal and this place has quickly become my favorite sandwich shop in the Mission.
author: Corey J.

description:
I don't get it.

The honey and I had been looking forward to trying Rhea's deli after seeing it featured on Check Please! Bay Area, but we were ultimately disappointed.  Maybe we expected too much after the oohs and ahhs, almost 5-star Yelp rating, and after seeing the long line there the weekend after the Check Please episode aired.  

While the Korean steak sandwich was delicious (good Korean saucey meat, crispy roll, spicy sauce, pickled peppers, etc.), I'm not sure if it was worth the hype, the 25 minute wait, or the $9 price tag.  With drink, we spent $12!

I'd be okay with the price point and the wait if this was a sit-down establishment, but it's anything but.  Tasty sandwich, but overhyped--I feel like Yelpers love this one because of its earnest, hipster, hole-in-the-wall-ness.
author: Alicia C.

description: Good, large sandwiches. Nice staff. Consistently tasty.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
I strolled in here about 2pm on a weekday in order to avoid the line. 

The good: I'll give Rhea's credit for having creative, delicious sandwiches. The Korean beef was definitely tasty and the katsu was crisp and everything a fried piece of pork should be. The balance of flavors was great, aided by the spicy, tangy slaw. The mild is more like medium, so if you can't handle your spice, beware.

The bad: What a freaking messy sandwich. I like myself a monstrosity of a sandwich sometimes, but I could barely eat the Korean beef sandwich without dripping juice and sauce all over the place. They should just serve that thing in a bowl. I can't ever see myself eating these sandwiches on the go. (And come on, sandwiches are meant to be portable.)

Also, how does it take 20 minutes to make two sandwiches when you're the only ones in the store? It's not as if you're waiting for the cabbage for the slaw to grow out back or something. The employees weren't nearly as friendly as other Yelpers had mentioned either... they were just alright.
author: Amy C.

description: Absolutely amazing. I've been here several times now and the guys working here are awesome to talk to. The sandwiches are most definitely the best in san fran. A MUST TRY!!!!
author: Darren P.

description:
If you're considering getting a sandwich, head to Ali Baba across the street instead and get a wonderful plate or shawarma.

Rhea's staff is super rude. The guy at the register told very loudly how he hates customers when they speak on the phone when paying. He says he wants to disturb them (speak loudly etc.) so they cannot speak on the phone. Who do you think you are dude? The most important man in the world so people stop their lives to hand out the money to you? Meanwhile the girl at the counter is singing along to the tunes and adds to his remarks. You are there trying to figure out how the hell you get a sandwich. (Fill in form, pay, take the form to the sandwich counter...)

Not worth it.
author: D T.

description:
Ike's Place, Rhea's has your number. Watch out.

I had been craving their veggie barbeque chicken sandwich for two days straight. Thick slices of seitan, garlicky sauce, and perfect Acme bread were invading my dreams. Then, today, I was finally home during the day so I could snag a sandwich during business hours. Bliss!

Besides the sandwiches (and really, aren't they enough?), Rhea's also has the usual liquor/convenience store fare in a non-skeevy environment. Perfect for last-minute liquor runs or cereal emergencies.
author: Renee T.

description: Certainly not your average liquor store. Seems like the full deli has some huge patronage. Unfortunately, I was there for the eclectic beverages but when someone has a sandwich called Han Solo, it raises eyebrows. I asked and they may or may not introduce a Chewbacca in the near future.
author: Kim N.

description:
Had their Korean Steak sandwich for lunch Thursday and wow, I really liked it!  This is another true foodie find that I never would have discovered on my own and once again another way in which Yelp has enriched my life.  

The guy at the counter was super cool and actually came outside to double-check with me regarding how I wanted the kim chi on the sandwich.  He genuinely cared and that really meant a lot to me.  I loved how they had an order form which helped make the order process a lot easier...I ordered mine with provolone.  Not big on aioli (hate mayo) so I ordered it without, but I definitely went with the chili garlic sauce which for me really added to the experience.

Certainly one of the most unusual and most memorable sandwiches I've had in a long time and I loved how all the ingredients came together.  Munching on this sandwich in my car on a rainy day made me really happy...it fogged my windows!  Now that's a great sandwich.

Looking forward to trying some of their other sandwiches as well, but I have a feeling that the next time I'm back there I'll most likely be ordering the same thing since I enjoyed it so much.  Sandwich heaven!
author: Roy N.

description:
I'm gonna guess you're probably like me.

You've been here before, usually after 11pm, and just to snatch up a few 6-packs or tallboys before heading to a house party in the neighborhood.  While you were paying, you noticed there was a deli counter to the right. 

"Oh."  You said to yourself, thinking little of it because it seems every other crusty Mission liquor store has some kind of odd deli counter, functional or not.

Then one day you decide that maybe you should actually try the deli because hey you've only ever bought beer here, you're tired of burritos and Ali Baba's sounds less than enticing.  Well, I've caught a live one here.

Get the Korean steak sandwich.  Just do it.  Disregard whatever anyone tells you, order it, keep an open mind and take it straight to the dome.  Personally I found it awesome and tasty to the point where I was eating every scrap that fell out of it and every sauce soaked chunk of bread I missed.  At $9 it's maybe a buck or two over what might normally suffice for a great sandwich but damn this thing is tasty.

I have the Diamond Heights (brisket) sandwich sitting on my counter right now and will eat it in about 50 minutes when my hunger strikes again.
author: Steven R.

description: I've only tried the Korean steak sandwich,sans cheese and it is extremely yum...just the right amount of spicyness to make it exciting and wonderfully overstuffed.Eat it as soon as you can.I made the mistake of carrying it around for an hour and the bottom bread was soggy from all the delicious juice...acme roll no less. It would be hard to go into Rhea's and not order this again!
author: Bleep S.

description:
*My review is about the overall service*
The sandwiches speak for themselves. They are very good. Well, the korean steak is, I've had that both times.

The first time I ordered a sandwich for delivery and got the wrong one, they didn't make a really strong effort to correct it, but they then sent out the right one, but in the turnaround I had to wait about 30 extra minutes. "Boo Hoo", I know, but turns out i was starving!

The second time, i figure I live fairly close, I 'll call ahead and pick the food up, makes it easier on them, easier on me .. not at all. After waiting around for 20 minutes! It was clear they had lost my order. I was asked "did you get your sandwich?" I replied "I just like hanging out in a liquor store in the middle of my lunch hour- no I didn't get anything." This was overheard by the manger/owner/overseer, whatever the guy is, who didn't do anything to correct it, or offer a "sorry about that" at least.

So, good sandwiches, hopefully they can work on their customer service a little
author: Lord R.

description:
im seeing a consensus reading the other reviews, but had to add my two cents cus this has happened entirely too many times lately.

sandwiches are AMAZING. i usually go for the valencia or korean steak. if they just improved their customer service, 5stars easily. i prefer rhea's sammiches over ike's.

big BUT: i usually call in my sammich order cus i dont want to wait 30min you sometimes have to wait when ordering there. 6months ago there was no issue doing this. everything would go according to plan. call the order in, go pick it up, enjoy sammich. 

over the past 6 months, ill call my order in. person taking the order will say 25min. that is fine. that gives me time to use the bathroom, put on some clothes, finish my bowl :), and have a leisurely 6block skate down valencia to rhea's. most likely, the weather is perfect. there is a smile on my face. i have learned to give them at least 10min more than what they estimate so that i am not standing around waiting. BUT WHY DO YOU TAKE PHONE ORDERS IF YOU DO NOT HONOR THEM?? i ordered my sammich on the phone over half an hour ago. you are really not BEGINNING to make it til now? its not like its even that busy in there. maybe 10 people milling around. NONE of which had ordered their sammiches in advance on the phone. i circumvented the wait for a reason. so why BS me on the phone? 

a few times, the girl in glasses/tattoos behind the register even had the AUDACITY to complain about customers who were impatiently waiting for their sammiches. she could be heard mumbling about the aioli and how long it takes to make a sammich. lets see here: there are at least 3 people pumping out sammiches behind that counter. lets say it takes a few minutes to make each one. there should not be a backup or people waiting around; ESPECIALLY NOT IF THEY PHONED THEIR ORDER IN 30MIN AGO.

sorry to rant so hard. i truly enjoy their sammiches. but the customer service here has just been terrible lately. bottomline: DONT TAKE PHONE ORDERS IF YOU ARE NOT GOING TO HONOR THEM. simple business ethics 101
author: Gionni B.

description: With all the reviews about the Korean Steak Sandwich, I had to give it a try and it was pretty damn good.  Such an unassuming place to make great sandwiches but that's what makes this place good.  It takes a little while to get your sandwich made so prepare for that.  The sandwich is smaller than what I thought it was going to be but what it lacked in overall size it made up in taste as it was just the right amount of spice with great meat.  Will definitely stop by again and recommend to my friends.
author: Blake B.

description:
When the line at Ike's gets too ridiculously long (and it always does), never fear -- there's a small liquor store/deli that is near Dolores Park that will satisfy all your munchies! And the place is so nondescript - your heart will smile from finding a real hidden gem.

I tried the first thing listed on the menu - Korean Steak Sandwich - and it did not disappoint. AT ALL.  It was spicy, the meat was well-marinated, and the portion size extremely generous. I recommend taking a companion to Dolores park and splitting the sandwich with someone. As ambitious as I was, I couldn't finish it on my own.

I don't know if our timing was right but we didn't call ahead nor did we wait longer than 10 minutes for our sandwiches on a sunny Saturday around 1pm. The easy and convenient experience was just the icing on the cake.

Can't wait to adventure back and try something new!  (and eat this again...)
author: May I.

description:
Quirky employees, a small well-supplied market, jars of kimchi, and delicious sandwiches. You fill out a little ordering slip and you can even select the spicy-nes level of your sandwich. I got the $8.99 Korean beef sandwich and was not disappointed. Even though it dripped everywhere and can get a little messy, sitting on the stools and people-watching was a nice way to pass time.  

There's a $5 minimum for credit cards, otherwise I think it's an extra 40 cents.
author: Connie C.

description:
There are only two things I love more than chocolate, men in skinny jeans and freshly baked Acme bread.

Where in the Mission can you find both?

Rhea's Deli and Market!

Alas, another culinary find means yet another number added to my ever expanding waistline.
author: Lisa W.

description: Fabulous  Korean Steak Sandwich.  Very friendly and helpful staff.   Large variety of beverages.   Even if there are only two people waiting for a sandwich it seems to take forever to get your order.  Takes a long time to make a sandwich At one time there was a bench out in front where you could eat your sandwich and watch the characters of Valencia street pass by.   The bench has disappeared and so has the fun of people watching while eating your sandwich.
author: Ann H.

description: Wow. I like sandwiches, and I've had some pretty good sandwiches. But I'd yet to have a sandwich that truly lives up to the hype until Rhea's Korean BBQ sandwich. I bought a Korean sandwich and headed home to split it with my boyfriend (mistake). By the time he made it to the table, I had already devoured my half and was about ready to start on his half. So good. Rhea's is also a great place to grab a snack, drink, and ice cream! Friendly staff and it's clean/organized inside! It can take a while to get your order especially during the lunch rush, so go at an off hour (I think they may also take phone orders, too).
author: Heather U.

description: Rheas is delicious. They're always friendly and always answer when you call to order. Bomb ass sandwiches and I can't get enough.
author: Ashley M.

description: The Korean Steak sandwich is a fine sandwich, but is not worth $13.09 (including tax). I used to be a regular, but I'm not going back. The regular price increases finally convinced me to go elsewhere.
author: Jared B.

description:
Based on sandwiches alone these guys get 5 stars for sure, hands down, they are my favorite sandwich shop in all of SF.  I love their Valencia St cold, it is amazing, as well as (obvi) the Korean steak sandwich.  

I love these guys' sandwiches so much, I wanted to have them served at my wedding-- well, not at the actual wedding but at the picnic lunch the next day.  Unfortunately, over the course of about 3 months, I stopped in to the deli in person 3 different times to ask about whether or not they could accommodate an order of about 50 sandwiches on a sunday morning at about 11am.  Each time I was told I needed to talk to a manager (who wasn't there), and I gave them my info, but never received a call.  I emailed them my request as well, but never heard back, no response whatsoever.  I understand they are super busy (duh, their sandwiches are killer), but it would have helped with my planning if I knew ahead of time they would not have worked out.

Keep up the killer work on the sandwiches, guys, but you should step it up on the customer service.
author: John D.

description:
Rhea's Deli (pronounced like Ray's Deli) is a pretty unassuming corner market but don't be fooled, those hipsters behind the deli counter know how to make a serious sando that would give Ike Shehadeh a run for this money.

My personal favorite is the Pork Katsu Sandwich. The lightly fried and breaded pork is nicely complemented with crunchy coleslaw and a spicy, tangy dressing. As noted by a ton of other Yelpers, the Korean Steak Sandwich is also worth the trip, but can be a little bit of a mess at the end. My girlfriend really likes their vegetarian sandwiches, but they've also got a fake bbq sandwich that looks pretty legit.

On weekdays the wait tends to be around 10-15min, but if you're headed there on the weekend I would recommend calling in your order.
author: Madhu P.

description:
It's been one week and I've had many meals in between, but I still remember how satisfied and happy I felt while I was savoring Rhea's Korean Steak Sandwich under SF's abnormally sunny and blue Friday skies. Perched on one of the benches right outside the unassuming liquor storefront of Rhea's, I had a hard time deciding if I should quickly devour the awesome sandwich or slowly dissect the sandwich to understand why this sandwich is so AWESOME.

The meat is not only authentically flavorful but TENDER. It's not tough or chewy so you wont get the awkward trailing mouth full of meat as you pull away from a bite.

The house pickled red onions are a wonderful addition to the sandwich. I personally like vinegared anything (love sunonomo!) but have never had vinegared ONIONS! It works magic here.

The organic ACME roll is crispy and light. It provides a great base for the flavors in between to shine. 

The people who works here are also very friendly and it seems like they truly enjoy producing delicious sandwiches. I love how they also have a great selection of drinks. They have a huge selection of ITO EN teas!

Remember to call ahead to place you order and get in the queue! I can't wait to come back to try the other sandwiches.
author: Mindy C.

description: The sandwhiches here are TOO DIE FOR. I had the Noe and I can honestly say it was probably the best sandwhich I've ever had in my life. My friends and I picked up sandwhiches and drinks here and then headed over to dolores park to enjoy our lunches in sunny bliss. We could not shut up about how delicious the sandwhiches were! Will definitely be back for more.
author: Ava S.

description: I love places that give thought to their vegetarian options. I had the veggie BBQ sandwich and it was pretty damn good.
author: Shaan S.

description: I have to agree with everyone. That korean steak sandwich is delicious. There was a bit of wait but nothing too bad. I will definitely be here again.
author: Christine H.

description:
My friend loves this place and is always telling me about their sandwiches when we pass by, so I thought I'd check them out. I got the BBQ Chicken and it was alright; nothing really to rave about. 
The spicy sauce is pretty tasty, but after a few bites it was all I could taste. There was also a lot of sauce; to the point where the bread got soggy and everything was drenched in it I couldn't tell what was what. It was about an hour before they closed the deli, so maybe the guy just had a long day and didn't care at that point? Who knows. 
I'd give this place one more go (at a different time in the day) to decide if it's really worth the hype.
author: Eilene G.

description: What a find! Saw this place highlighted on Check Please on channel 9. My husband and I drove into SF to try the sandwiches...amazingly awesome taste and creations. If you have not tried you are missing out on a culinary treat.  Gargamel is fantastic!!!
author: Nancy M.

description:
unimpressed with the korean steak sandwich.  at almost $11 i don't feel like i'm getting my money's worth

people are nice though! A for service
author: Jeffry C.

description:
I heard about this place recently and gave it a try for Thursday lunch. I showed up about 11:25 (the deli opens at 11:30), put in my order, and waited. And waited. And waited.

I got my sandwich at 11:45. 15 minutes for a sandwich. There was one guy in front of me when I came in.

The sandwich (Korean steak) was great. Beautifully fresh roll. Delicious, tender meat. Nicely sauced.Just the right amount of spiciness. 

Good eats, just be prepared to wait.
author: David G.

description: The Korean steak Sandwich is delicious, only don't get it twisted, it doesn't cost no $8.45 as listed on Yelp and other places online.  They charge $11 dollars for it now.  Yeah, there are no discounts left on Valencia street my friends.
author: Alex M.

description:
Just finished a monster Korean steak sandwich, good and spicy! The cheddar cheese seemed like an odd idea, but I ended up liking it. My wife's vegetarian barbecue "chicken" sandwich was great too - sweet, tangy, and tasted a lot like chicken...

Service is quick and pleasant, and they make and sell their own Kimchi. (I can't vouch for its authenticity, but it's delicious, and beats trekking down to Kukje in Daly City.)
author: Eric S.

description:
I've been away from yelp for like eight months (might be longer, but I'm too lazy to click back now...), and Rhea's vegan chicken sandwich brought me out of the dark. 

Dudes, I have a job that's sucking the life blood out of me, and I am taking ten minutes from my hellish work day of people screaming at me, "DRUPAL! DRUPAL! BUGZILLA!!! eCOMMERCE! HELP! GO! SHIT! FIX IT! NOW!!!!!!" to write this review. I will pay for it later, but I have to let the world know (in my words) how good their vegan barbecue chicken sandwich thingy is. 

Effin' DELICIOUS.

There. 

Go to Rhea's, you stupid veggie idiots who haven't already. You just have to get there before they close the deli counter, at 7:00 PM. Which I'll probably never be able to do again, thanks to eCommerce.

Help me out and eat my vegan sandwiches for me and I will live vicariously through you all. Thanks! Back to the bugs...
author: Lisa T.

description:
OMFG if you haven't gone here(or had it delivered) you are seriously missing out.

I've gotten sando's here 10+ times, so this review is a long time coming.

Love it, so good, so totally worth the wait.  Ordering a few items right now for delivery to cure my hangover.  That and Gatorade.  Nice.
author: Chase N.

description: I wouldn't have noticed the place while looking for food, but luckily my friend heard they had good sandwiches. We were both very happy with our sandwiches and only waited about 5-10 minutes. If difficult decisions are painful for you,  you might want to skip this place. Their entire menu looked delicious,  plus they have a build your own sandwich option.
author: Briana B.

description:
I got into an argument with the girl while here.  

She thinks Rhea's is pronounced like "ree-ahhs" as in diarrhea.

Silly girl.

Anyways...

I am a sandwich man.  

I find myself always trying to "chase the dragon" for new taste combinations and flavors.

Once, in a desperate state at around 4:30am, I placed a dry brick of ramen in between two pieces of stale wheat bread and ate it with cholula sauce.  

The sandwich was surprisingly good.

The fire the morning after was surprisingly bad.

You know what else is suprisingly good?

The Korean BBQ sandwich at Rhea's.

7x7 says Rhea's is the new Ike's.  

I agree.

And a ramen/wheat/cholula sandwich is the new spicy fiber flush laxative.

Save the poop jokes.

Get a Korean sando at Rhea's before some food network show ruins it for us.

Potty.
author: Archie R.

description:
I was going to this place before they even had sandwiches.  It has always been one of the best corner stores around, with a large selection of quality goods at a fair price and John, the owner, is a great guy.

I was a bit concerned when the deli first opened since it did impact the amount of shelf space.  But the sandwiches have more than made up for not being able to find a meat thermometer in a pinch.  The key to their sandwiches are the simple fresh  ingredients the the high quality bread.  I am in for a pork katsu almost every weekend now.  Also great at the Van Ness, the 18th st., and the Dolores St.

If you are heading to delores park, or just happen to be in the area, you should definitely check this place out.
author: Lenza M.

description: I was early for a doc appointment and walking up and down in search of some food. I hadn't heard about this place, but it looked good and inviting and boy was I in for a treat. I ordered Barneys Rubble and it was super delicious. I can't wait to get back and try more of their sando's. I must have been there at an off time (Thursday at noon) because it was completely empty. If you find yourself in the area and want something decently priced and super yummy - go here and give it a try.
author: Conny F.

description:
I'm glad my mom doesn't know how to use the internet because she might read this.

This is where I get my kimchi when I run out of my momma's homemade kimchi that I get imported (read: driven up either by myself or visiting family) from LA. 

No, it's not perfect like my mom's but it's fine enough and that means it's pretty darn good. Better than any of that unhappy looking factory en-masse produced stuff injected with God-knows-what they keep stocked at Korean grocery stores. I would rather go kimchi-less than give in and buy that junk.

Don't forget to bring the kimchi mason jar back to get your $2 jar deposit back.

So until the day I learn how to reproduce Mamma Kim's kimchi, Rhea's is it. 

Their sandwiches are also EXCELLENT and absolutely well worth the wait.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I'm also not sure what all the fuss is about for the Korean Steak Sandwich. The bread was good, but the rest was just OK. There was also way too much lettuce. I ordered the "mild" -- I'd call it a medium anywhere else. I'm guessing that the "hot" would blow your head off.

I might try other sandwiches of theirs at some point, but I'm not rushing back.
author: Paul L.

description: I can't believe it, I have a new favorite at Rhea's! Their semi-nouvo Wonderwoman sandwich is perfect, for me, as is. They make it spicy, it's still lean with a great spicy cheese. I wanted something new, other than my favorite meatless BBQ sandwich which was my staple 5 star sandwich. I gotta say, I've had a few and although these two are my favorites cause they're spicy, you can't go wrong. Love ya Rhea's XOXOXO
author: Jessica f.

description:
Such an amazing deli.  I absolutely love their sandwiches and the fact that they deliver makes for a perfect lazy weekend day.  The boar's head meats and cheeses paired with acme bread makes for a tasty combo that comforts the taste buds and the soul. 

I am a huge fan of the chicken katsu but am bummed it is on a "hiatus" bring back chicken katsu and save the world :)
author: Sunshine S.

description:
Rhea's Korean steak sandwich is as good as it gets.  I was skeptical at first, but once you take your first bite you'll see that the meat, chili spread and kimchee really do go together on a roll.  It's not cheap but you can share it.

I just wish there are more spots to eat in the market, it's always packed when I go.
author: Carol S.

description: I ordered the Valencia sandwich because I was starving.  I am only half way through the sandwich and am absolutely delighted. I like saucy sandwiches and the dijon + aioli combo add flavor and texture to the sandwich. Plus it is huge and really filling. I'll likely save half for dinner or lunch tomorrow!
author: Maryanna Q.

description:
The Chicken Katsu Sandwich is the way to go. Everyone thinks the Bulgogi Sandwich is the best but I don't think so. 

Tip: Call it in. The wait is really long at peak lunch time hours on the weekend.
author: Jason T.

description: Awesome sandwichs and extremely friendly employees. The proprietor of this fine sandwich establishment is a real character and extremely entertaining. He had our whole group in stitches as we waited for our sandwiches and he did expressions to everyone that called the store! Definitely recommend the Korean BBQ sandwich! I'm going to have the worst cravings when I go back to LA and it isn't readily available to me.
author: David C.

description: The Korean steak sandwich is everything I could wish for in a sandwich... Flavorful marinated steak, spicy sauce, grilled onions and pickles. ACME bread tops it off. Perfectly balanced and assembled! The spicy sweet aioli will have you wanting more!
author: Christine P.

description: Try the Van Ness sandwich created by the homie George on the super secret dolo menu. Katsu with bacon and a bunch of delicious sauces (sriracha, ranch and BBQ) that you would think work together, but it does!
author: Valerie F.

description:
With so many great sandwich places, why would you go here?  That's what I thought the first five times my wife asked me to check it out.

But after the first time, I'm liking it a lot.  The sandwiches are tasty and creative.  Kinda like Ike's but with a Kung Fu Panda flair.

Its a toss-up for me ... between the Korean Steak Sandwich or Katsu Sandwich (pork, chicken).  Both thoroughly satisfying.

The guys at counter are relaxed and friendly.  Great value for food.  No ambiance, but half way through a sandwich ... you are already in a mild food coma. :)
author: J B.

description:
The place is basically a convenience store with a food stand inside of it.

The first time I got there, the food portion was closed! It closes every other Monday for cleaning.

I came back the next day. Of course I ordered the Korean Steak BBQ Sandwich [~$8], medium spicy! I did my research.

[sweet?] Marinated Korean BBQ, cheddar cheese, grilled onion, raw onion, lettuce, some spicy sauce mixture (crushed red peppers), sandwiched between a french roll (ran out of sweet rolls). I'm loving the fusion here. The mix of sweet and spicy ingredients was confusing to me, it threw me off. I still devoured it, but I wish it were one way or the other. I'm not sure which ingredient was sweet, but maybe ordering it either mild or spicy would help.
author: Rahil P.

description: Great little place! Who would have ever guessed a little liquor store could boast a deli that makes such outstanding sandwiches?! When we went, there was quite a line but their Korean Steak Sandwich was completely worth $10 and the 20 minute wait.
author: Athena T.

description: So delicious...tasty, tasty, and the people who work there are so helpful and nice.  There are directions posted on how to order 1. Fill out the order sheet located to the left of the cash register, 2. Take your order sheet to the cashier and pay, 3. Listen for your name to be called.  The wait is well worth it...our wait 35 minutes.  It's fun to people watch and the employees will keep you posted.  No seats open at the bar/window eating area so we took a short walk over to Delores Park and enjoyed a picnic with the best ever sandwiches.
author: Lesley K.

description: Used to love this spot, but it's gone downhill. Vegetarians beware-- I got a real chicken sandwich instead of the vegetarian BBQ sandwich, which I used to love. Sandwich was cold, and as soon as I noticed the chicken instead of seitan, I had to trash it. There goes $10.
author: Crank Y.

description:
Super young guys running the place  producing amazing yums for your tum. 

They are the new Ikes, and they deliver, and you dont have to wait 1 hr. 

Unassuming small place which started out selling cheese and kim chee ( which I loved too) now has some of the best sandwiches in San Francisco. 

The veggie chicken, is amazing and I really tastes like chicken. 
Korean BBQ- amazing! Hits the and every spot every time. 
Chicken katsu is better in their sandwiches then i've had in Japantown

LOVE that when they ask you for spicy they really give it to you
Did I mention they deliver ;)  
I ordered  by phone they were there within 20 min. 

I'm hooked and I like it.
author: Tasha A.

description: Very tasty korean steak sandwich; it was huge (I only ate half the sandwich and was full), spicy (my lips were tingling!), and delicious. I'm excited to go back and try their other sandwiches. I recommend calling your order ahead, so you just run in and quickly pick it up.
author: Erin H.

description:
I tried it for the first time the other day...

I thought this place would be a real deil place, but it is inside a liquor store.. Decent selection of beers..

I tried the Korean BBQ sandwich since it was advertised and recommended.. It was good a good intimation of a real Korean style BBQ type of meat (THINK bulgogi style) It was flavorful with some kick of kim chee and peppers. ($8) for a sandwhich on a roll type of bread. 

TIP: if your hungry you might need two to kill that hunger..
author: kent c.

description:
I had a Rhea's vegan bbq chicken sandwich last year and have been craving it since. I can't walk though the Mission without thinking about how much I'd like to eat another one. It was so good! There are just so many other places to go in the neighbourhood and I feel guilty for wanting Rhea's sandwiches EVERY DAY.

I love that you get a little check sheet and can construct your own perfect sandwich with little to no confusion. It's hard to miscommunicate with a check sheet - dim sum places have obviously figured this out.
author: Malloreigh M.

description:
This liquor store sells amazing sanwiches on 
Acme rolls.  There are about a dozen or more to choose from, with something for everyone.  We had their popular Korean BBQ Steak with spicy hot sauce and the Buffalo Pesto Chicken.  They were both delicious, containing meat, cheese, homemade aeoli and lettuce/veggies.  There are three people making them, yet there can be a wait.  Suggest going after 1:30 PM.  I suggest you not tell too many of your friends about this place until they expand or become a multi-store outfit.
author: John K.

description: I am so happy that there are other faux meat veggie sandwiches in SF besides Ikes and Love n Haight. Rhea's rocks out two amazing sandwiches: the BBQ veggie chicken with cabbage slaw and spicy sauce and the Church St, an monster concoction of veggie chicken bites, swiss cheese, avocado, lettuce, tomato, pickles, honey mustard, ranch and garlic aioli. Both sandwiches are messy but so worth the repeated hand washing and mouth wiping. I've ordered both for delivery in the SOMA/Mission border and they always arrive super quick from friendly  cute bike messengers to boot. Seriously, these sandwiches rule. Kick your crappy cheese sandwich to the curb.
author: Cori W.

description:
Are you a fan of chicken katsu? 

Are you a fan of sandwiches? 

Are you a fan of awesomeness? 

If you answered yes to all of the above, then you will love Rhea Deli's CHICKEN KATSU SANDWICH! YES, YOUR EYES ARE NOT PLAYING TRICKS ON YOU; I said chicken katsu sandwich! 

If that isn't enough to convince you, just check out the pictures because they pretty much scream delicious. And this sandwich did not disappoint. The chicken katsu was crispy, the slaw and sauce were killer, and the Acme roll was fresh and crunchy! 

My friend had the bulgogi with cheese sandwich, and she adores Vietnamese sandwiches; this particular interpretation ended up being a bit too wet (the meat was too juicy?). 

Take your sandwiches to Dolores Park, take in the sun, and play with the millions of doggies trying to eat your food!
author: Leslie T.

description:
Another dynamite sandwich spot located inside a market/store. I was gonna just do the regular routine and hit up Roxie's as I do every week. My homie suggested it to me to try, so thought we'd give it a go. 

I got the Korean steak sandwich cuz that's what's hot in the streets. Not only hot in the streets, but it got me hot in the pants. HOT damn my loins yearn for this sandwich. It brought me on a trip. Had the asian-esqe flavor I've only experienced at King Foot Subs, combined with awesome Dutch Crunch bread. Those two addends equate to a flavor smash I have yet to experience from any other sandwich. I pretty much destroyed that sandwich. 

The gf got the Judah. Anytime you throw pesto and chicken together, you're gonna get some heat. The combination of the two was in the words of my homie Tony the Tiger, "GRRRREEEEEATTT." 

I can't wait to come back and try the katsu sandwich. I see a hawaiian sandwich explosion in my near future. =)
author: Alvin P.

description:
(more of a 3.5)

When a friend told me they had katsu sandwiches here, I immediately put a visit to Rhea's at the top of my to do list.  I love me some katsu (preferably pork, but chicken will do in a pinch).

Staff were really laid back and friendly;  their sandwich creations sounded so good I was drooling.

The Pork katsu sando was, unfortunately, disappointing.  Combining katsu with slaw and other stuff was interesting (in a good way) the first few bites, but then the lack of meat kicked in.  Look closer at the pictures - cutlets a little under a quarter inch of meat in thickness?   Even L&L isn't that stingy.  IMO one of the critical aspects of a good sandwich is ratios.  Bread was a bit on the chewy side for me, but I guess it could be personal preference - not knocking anything off for that, though that plus the slightly chewy nature of a pork cutlet, and your jaw gets a slight workout.

Also had a few bites of the other signature, the Korean Steak Sandwich (i.e. bulgogi I believe), which was much better.  A good amount of juicy, tender, well flavored, thinly sliced beef,  with bread that holds up fairly well to the juices.  The bread:meat:filling ratio here was more on the spot, with a good flavor profile too.

Size-wise, they're not humongous, but for the price they could be a tad bigger (or include some candy or something like other places charging the same).

Would I go out of my way for a sandwich here?  No, but I would stop by if in the area and feeling like a sandwich.
author: T C.

description:
- best sandwich hands down is the korean steak sandwich.  

- recommend phoning in the order ahead of time

- limited seating at the counter.
author: Jerry W.

description:
The reason why I came here because this line:
"Rhea's Deli is truly a hidden gem. Hidden inside of a liquor store," by Rita C. She got ROTD 2 days ago.

"Hidden gem inside of a liquor store in Mission? Shit, Man, i gotto go there!"
Something like that.
I thought that Valencia Street and Mission street are same thing like Clement and Irving. It was, before. But, it's not the same anymore.
QUE PASO?

So, about the Rhea's.
The place is FXXXin'GOOD!!!
1. Korean Steak Sandwich is FXXXin'GOOD.
2. Chicken Katsu Sandwich is FXXXin'GOOD.
3. Polk Katsu Sandwich is FXXXin'GOOD.
4. Kim Chee is FXXXin'GOOD.

The Kim Chee is something special. 
But when I heard the price, I thought " What a rip-off 6 bucks for a 16oz? " But I had to try it because who's gonna buy Kim Chee in the Mission district? It didn't make a sense to me that selling Kim Chee in Mission. 
So i had to get it.
A guy in the store said, " You'll get 2 dollars back when you get the bottle back."
I was like, "Uh-Huh."
The Kim Chee is vacuumed pack.

This is a warning for a person who is thinking getting the Kim Chee from Rhea's.
Watch out when you are opening the top of the bottle.
Make sure you are at right front of a kitchen sink because the Kim Chee will explode!!!
It is compressed, pressed, squeesed into a 16oz bottle, so, you will see the Kim Chee explode like the Kim Chee rising twice high of the bottle.
At the moment of the Kim Chee rising, it reminded me of the movie "Alien" when the baby Alien came threw out of the guy's lower belly.
FXXXin'GOD, that scared me to hell.
Not Alien.
The Kim Chee!
I thought the Kim Chee is alive.

But the "live" Kim Chee was excellent.
I loved the deep sensible hot chili flavor with such a fresh crunchy Nappa-cabbage. It's not the same like that King's label you see at Safeway.
Btw, I have met an old Korean man before telling me that good Kim Chee don't smell bad as you think. He was right. The Rhea's Kim Chee doesn't smell that badly.

Talkin' about Kim Chee is endless.

I didn't see any Korean guys but so what?
Guys here are really nice.
The Best Deli in the city!!!

I'll be back here very soon to return the bottle to get another one.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I have a screaming three month old and my partner came home from work exhausted. We've both been craving sandwiches for some time now so I turned to my trusted Yelp to see what awesome place had enough forethought and wherewithal to offer delicious sandwich delivery.

Can I just say I freaking LOVE you guys?
Thanks for the recommendation. This place rocked my world.

I called the place and some sweet, awesome guy picked up on the first ring (good start). I'm sure I sounded like a jackass- I knew I wanted the chicken katsu somethingorother and something vegetarian but wasn't decisive (having been in the service industry before I know how annoying that can be). He offered up great suggestions and was incredibly patient, kind, and even kept up the witty banter (which I definitely appreciate) with me while I made my decisions.

His suggestions:
The Chicken Katsu Sandwich (I got it mild- he thought I was a wuss but was too polite to say so... I'm glad I got it mild. I am a wuss. And it was still a tad spicy but incredibly delicious.)

The Vegetarian Sandwich w/ avocado, lettuce, tomato, pickle, havarti & swiss cheese, and garlic mayo.

Both sandwiches were on point. My partner couldn't stop bragging about the vegetarian sandwich and the chicken katsu hit the spot.

They also deliver beer & cigarettes. Not that I'm interested in that option with a three month old but I do believe that's a major score... and I got a six pack of Heineken for my partner and the beers arrived COLD (especially amazing for how far away we live).

IF YOU DO ORDER DELIVERY- keep in mind that these guys deliver everything on their bicycles. I didn't know that and felt like a complete tool when the guy was sweating and out of breath at my doorstep. Despite having to travel to hell and back for me the delivery guy was as sweet as a freaking peach, super cordial and happy to ride to the middle of nowhere to satisfy my sandwich fix. So if you are a lazy bitty like me, and just HAVE to have delivery, please take that into account and tip well. 

All in all, awesomely successful.
I'm super glad I called the guy who took my order my "Sandwich Fairy Godmother."

That's not a phrase I throw around wildly- and he definitely deserved the accolade.
author: Heather J.

description:
I love this place.

The vegetarian barbecued chicken sandwich is pretty magical. So are the grilled cheese sandwiches. The staff is super nice.

If you want to get something during lunch hour, it's probably a good idea to call the order in ahead of time, because they get pretty busy.
author: Valerie W.

description:
F'ing awesome!

The Korean steak sandwich is just about the perfect combination of flavors I want in a sandwich.

It does take about 15 minutes to get your sandwich depending on how many people are there, but hey, it's worth it.
author: Sam K.

description:
Just had the katsu sandwich here for lunch and it was absolutely rock solid. Crispy-on-the-outside pork cutlet on a fantastic Acme roll. There was BBQ sauce, hot sauce, tangy coleslaw and it all came together like Voltron to form one badass sandwich. Rhea's Deli is a must try.

Pro tip: they deliver for free by bicycle throughout the Mission
author: Aaron V.

description: Expect to wait a long time for a mid-twenties under-achiever to make your sandwich, but you'll be glad you did. The Korean steak sandwich is ridiculously good.
author: Roger E.

description:
Thanks to Lolia S. we just had to try the Korean steak sandwich (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=eTojdsxA3xRMOAAWg_kk2g) from Rhea's. My BMF went inside to order our sandwich. He was inside the store so long I'd thought he cheated on me and devoured the entire sandwich himself. I wouldn't have blamed him though.

After just one bite I determined this was one of the best hot sandwiches I'd ever had. Excellent bread, tender beef, crunchy vegetables and a nice spicy sauce. It was well worth the wait. Next time I'm getting my own!
author: Sara A.

description:
I live a block away, so it's high time I tried Rhea's. Thanks to a friend's recommendation, I now know it's not just another nondescript corner market. 

I got the Van Ness Street - chicken katsu, bacon, pepper jack, slaw, pickles sauces, love etc.

Fully delicious and satisfying on many levels. Great mix of flavors and textures. I'll be back to sample the rest of the goodness!
author: Aaron S.

description:
If only their sandwiches were tasteless piles of cardboard, I wouldn't find myself wandering over to Rhea's at least once a week.  Bulgogi & katsu sandwiches are top notch.  Great, fresh ingredients and friendly staff.  There's a wait but you can always have your goods delivered by TCB Courier for FREE with a min $10 purchase.

Buy their kimchee.  Better than your Korean Grandma's.  Promise.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Is Rhea's REALLY running this coupon in the SFWeekly?
author: Amit S.

description:
Being a vegetarian who also eats healthy my goal of course is to try and get as far away from both of those without stepping over the line. 

I had biked by this place a gazillion times and seen their sign for a Bar-B-Q Vegetarian Chicken Sandwich and never gone in (probably because it was just a market) and instead settled for Bi-Rite's and Oscar's yummy sandwiches. However, I finally made the leap and as soon as I finished my sandwich at home I literally had the urge to go back and order another one. Granted it was pricey, but it was most likely that good.

Add on the fact that they have an amazing beer selection (Belgians, 21st Ammendment, Rogue - including Hazelnut Brown Nectar!!!), chocolate and specialty foods which would surprise you this place truly is a gem.
author: daimian holiday s.

description: One of my favorite sandwich spots in the city. Definitely worth checking out (but try to avoid peak lunch hours as it can get a little crazy). Go for the Korean steak or the Mission.
author: Marc M.

description:
I want to give this place 3.5 stars but I'll round up to 4.  After hearing that this place serves Korean steak sandwiches I had to come try.  There are more and more Korean fusion items I have seen popping up here in the city.  (i.e. Korean tacos at Namu which are bomb by the way)

The steak in the sandwich had an excellent marinade and they spice it up pretty well enough to clear up your sinus.  Mix the steak with your usual lettuce, onions, tomatoes in between a roll and the sandwich just becomes a sandwich.  With so many "sandwich shops inside mini market" places to choose from, it is hard to give them more than 4 stars.
author: Danny P.

description:
The Korean steak sandwich is oh so delicious!  I orginally came here with the intention of ordering some tacos, but I just couldn't pass on the sandwich.  Saving the tacos for a future visit.

I had to painfully wait 15 mins before devouring my food - my coworkers and I had to take the food back to the office.  Everything about the sandwich was good - perfect bread, lots of meat, and cheese!  I also had a taste of the katsu sandwich - no bueno.  The katsu was very thin and kinda hard.  I wouldn't order this.

You can also buy kim chee here.  I paid about $6 for a small can.  It had too much ginger for my taste, so I wouldn't buy it again.

I'll return for the steak sandwich and to try the tacos.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
When I crave a sandwich I crave a rhea's sandwich. No Joke these sandwiches are bomb. I get angry with myself every now and then for spending 9 bucks on a sandwich, but i can't help it!
One Complaint tho
Didn't get avo in the sandwich I ordered the other day and it just wasn't the same so I called them up to let them know. They asked if they could do anything, but if I suggest something I would feel like an uppity bitch. They should offer a dollar off coupon or something like that for messing up an order.  Its not like I'm trying to be stingy, but if it ain't got the avo its not worth it. Just sayin' 
Make coupons or something...
author: Astrid I.

description:
I love the sandwiches here.  I have never been disappointed.  My favorite probably is the pork katsu.  

Not only do they have great sandwiches, they also have a pretty good selection of soft drinks and alcoholic beverages.  If you don't want to take your sandwich far, there is a counter and some benches that you can sit at.  This is one of my favorite places to get a quick bite.
author: Michael N.

description:
**Korean Beef Sandwich MEDIUM***

Open til 2 AM on the weekends?  You mean if I'm lucky and they don't run out of Acme Ciabatta Rolls I can have a Korean Beef Sandwich??  I had this 2 lbs monstrosity on the recommendation of my very hungover roommate.  I read the reviews and decided to call it in instead of waiting in line.  Lucky me, no line at all.  The fella making my sandwich said he'd make it special...hmmm how special?  He hands me the sandwiches and my hand hits the counter.  I didn't expect that.  It was so big I made a mental note to eat only half.

I took the 1st bite and I had tunnel vision.  Everything around me disappeared and it was me and my sandwich.  Wow, it was soooo good I didn't breath.  I just kept biting and chewing and smacking and yea you get the point.  Instantly, I thought of my good friend Riss and imagined her sitting in front of me experiencing this beautiful moment and I can see her moaning and doing her little dance w/ wide eyes.  I told her about it and she screamed at me..."why didn't you get me one?"  This sandwich makes you lose all your thoughts.  You think of no one.  You become this selfish little person and can only think of yourself and that sandwich.  When you're done...you don't care.  Sigh.
author: D C.

description:
The sandwich lines are not as long as another popular sandwich shop at 16th and Sanchez, but these sandwiches are comparable.

The Korean Steak Sandwich just melts in your mouth (five stars).  I like to compare the veggie bbq chicken sandwich to eating a sponge; it was that bad (two stars).  I will still give them four stars for pleasant customer service and will return for the Korean Steak Sandwich.
author: Coyote B.

description:
Their Korean Steak sandwich is amazing... when they have stock. We try to order take-out from here but they're always out of something... meat... lettuce... bread...

Seriously? a deli that ran out of bread to make sandwiches? Comon now. Pull your sh*t together.

We order for delivery so I have no idea regarding the actual store itself or what it looks like.
author: Brandon O.

description:
Heard about this place from my friend's food blog, www.urbanstomach.com.  Ordered the Korean steak sandwich thinking, how hot could this be . . . I eat kimchee all the time.  Ah hem, it was a fire cracker in my mouth when you include the jalapenos and sriracha!  

It's true -- this place looks like a typical liquor store from the outside.  So its strange to see their collection of Cowgirl Creamery cheese collection and imported chocolate bars.  I was the only one in line and it took a good 15 minutes for my sandwiches to get made -- worth every bite!

I want to thank the deli guys for being accommodating.  I stopped them mid-way because my son is allergic to eggs and dairy so he can't have the cheese and aioli -- no problem, they threw out the bread and started again.

I've made a funny video about Rhea's at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gNB4UDGTGRo.  You'll get to see my son's reaction face!

We ordered a Chicken Katsu sandwich too -- husband says equally delish!
author: Sabrina G.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said. 

korean. steak. sandwich. 

DOOOOOO EHHHHTTTT!!!!

bread was just right too. not the hard stuff that can rip the roof of your mouth open. no bueno.

hella cool dudes, too. yup. hella. take advantage of calling in your order for lunch. easy peasy.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
The sandwiches are good, but the wait is horrific.
5 minutes to order, 20 minutes to get a sandwich made...
30 minute lunch break...do the math....

With unemployment so high, one would think the owner would hire some help to expedite the process of getting the product to the customers.
author: Hal S.

description:
Being the foodies that I am, I went today to try their sandwiches and was very disappointed. It's like a poor imitation of Ike's on 16th street. They gave us all the wrong bread (I heard they were running out of bread but they didn't say anything to me). Only the bread was toasted, the inside was all cold, the portions of meat were little. They even copied the carmel lollipops that Ike's sometimes put on in the bag for free. 

The menu (and the prices of course) are outdated...probably from years ago. I believe this is to pull the customers in. The menu on line says the specialty sandwiches prices range from 6.95 to 8.95 NOT  Everything was either 8.95 and 9.95. 

Go to Ike's, I guarantee you will not be disappointed. They'll even throw in a bag of chips for free. The entire sandwich is toasted, no cold center here!
author: May G.

description: YOU'RE GONNA SEE JESUS! That's what the very friendly cashier guy said to us when my wife and son each ordered their Korean BBQ Sandwich. You know what? We didn't see Jesus (since I took a bite to try) but it was a damn good sandwich. My wife rated hers as  one of the best sandwiches she's ever had. Included in her list are the muffalettas  and Po' Boys in New Orleans and some really great Banh Mi sandwiches. I ordered a Reuben and wasn't disappointed either. Huge sandwiches, great quality, fast and friendly service (the nice guy even gave a dog in the store a cookie). BTW, don't forget to purchase a jar of homemade kimchee before leaving. Again, one of the best I've ever had. Hey, maybe we didn't see Jesus because we're Buddhists.
author: Frank F.

description:
The sandwiches are amazing!  The wait was a little long, but completely worth it.  

The only thing that kept me from giving Rhea's 5 stars, aside from the wait, was the TERRIBLE elevator jazz music that I had to listen to as I waited for my sandwich.
author: Sam S.

description:
Had to wait because the sandwich being made in front of mine was being delivered to Dolores Park via bike messenger.

Cool.

Soon after I received my veggie chicken on an acme roll, stuffed with veggies and basted in BBQ sauce.

Delicious.

Only wish I had been headed to Dolores Park.

Jealous.
author: Jason B.

description:
I have a new favorite Sandwich shop on the Mission.  Sorry, "The Sandwich Place"...I've found Another.  Rhea's fulfills my sandwich needs beyond what you ever could.  

The Korean steak sandwich is positively orgasmic.  Love at first bite.  Possibly the best sandwich I've ever had.  The End.
author: Ron C.

description:
OK, The Good

Korean BBQ sandwich just awesome. Love the bold flavors and because of a possible early onset of an ulcer I had to temper my love of Hot to Mild. Whomp, whomp whomp :( The mayo and the kim chee in the sandwich really brought out the nice flavor in the bul go gi. I do wanna try the new Soprano, should've named it the "Bada Bing" cuz the ingredients speak my language. There's something sexy about the words Roast Beef and sandwich.

The Bad
The sandwich was great but a little small for $10.00 and I have to say the next time I order a sandwich here I'm going to have to just call it in. It took closer to 20 minutes wait for the sandwich to reach my hand. Also be prepared to write down your order to give to the cashier. It's not like a regular sandwich spot where you order the sandwich and tell the makers what you want. Also the last bad thing is that this is straight up hipster central. Growing up in the city I used to remember this as one block away from gang territory where you'd have to be on guard at all times. Nope, not this time... strange striped tight ass tank tops, Plaid Board shorts and an overabundance of hipster swankiness fashion that just made me shake my head and actually long for the days of striding, no... tap dancing in fear walking near these parts of the woods. Now it's just taken over by hipsterville US of Europe. I won't be back in these parts unless I need to pick a friend up or to change my tires on South Van Ness. Holy Crap I guess hipsters are less violent and better for the economy than gangbangers who claim a piece of land owned by the city. So kudos to the owner this place fits everyone walking these parts of the neighborhood with cash to burn. Smart and I'm takin notes for my future food ventures...
author: graham c.

description:
Their menu has changed drastically since my last review, but you'll see that the 5 stars remain. 

Sandwich must haves: Noe St, Han Solo, katsu
author: Doug H.

description:
Korean Steak Sandwich: Awwwweeesome.

Pork Katsu Sandwich: Great.


This is a great place to try out different sandwiches. I really like the Korean steak sandwich after all the reviews telling me to try it. I got the pork katsu to go and it was cold, so I have to try it again when its warmer and more crunchy. 


Will definitely come back to trry the menu!
author: Derek N.

description: KOREAN BBQ SANDWICH. I have nothing new to add to the already raving reviews of this sandwich. Its a must have. Go get it. Now.
author: Melinda L.

description: Everybody should know the thing to do on a sunny Monday afternoon is to go get a sandwich and some beer from Rhea's, and go to Dolores Park :)  Korean BBQ Sandwich = a stomach full of bliss.
author: Robert F.

description:
This place gives Ike's a serious run for its money.  I just finished the Veggie BBQ sandwich and it was delicious.  Warm roll crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, pickled cabbage and red onions, and slices of maybe the best fake chicken I've tasted. Delicious.

Note: You get to choose your level of spicy, and medium was HOT.  Next time I'll be going for mild.
author: danielle p.

description:
After years of coming in here to buy mixers and other typical corner store items, I finally tried a sandwich one day and to my surprise, it was quite possibly the most delicious thing I ever tasted. Now I can't help myself from coming back every week just to have that heavenly cheese induced food coma. 

I'd recommend the veggie BBQ sandwich, but be careful, it can be spice-Y. I also have a warm spot for an expertly made three cheese sandwich.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Whoa James! I had no idea! I have been looking for a good sandwich joint in the city for the last 5 years. This is the best sandwich I think I have ever had and I have only tried the Valencia. 
Way wasn't this around when we lived on Cunningham alley?! 
I guess that is a good thing and now it gets me back over that way a lot more. Stroll to 19th and Valencia, bring the kid, order a sandwich and then off to the park.
When we come off a trip out of town we go strait from the airport to Rhea's Deli now. no joke.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Look, I have a problem and I want you to know about it. Rhea's has homemade Kim Chee. I am viciously, hopelessly addicted to Mama K and theirs is the purest shit around. They also have mysterious mason jars of daikon, asian pear, and other korean pickles and they are all precious and magnificent.  I have been visiting, on average, once every two weeks for my "re-up" of stinking, gingery, tingly cabbage. Just put it in my veins.

Also they have sandwiches, which are nearly as good as Bi Rite, but without the line and the hot yipsters in yoga pants.
author: EDW L.

description: Seriously?!?  40 mins wait for a sandwich?!?  And we called in for the order 10 mins. prior...The sandwich is good but not that good!!
author: Daniel K.

description: Nice place. Basic. Got the Korean Steak Sandwich. it was tasty but got very soggy. decent kick.
author: Josh D.

description:
Some kind of orthodontic appliance for maxillary expansion comparable to that of a car jack can only help you, not hurt you, when attempting to unhinge the jaw and anchor thy ivory rows around Rhea's juicy, drippy Korean Steak (bulgogi) or bone dry double-stack Chicken Katsu Sandwiches. 

But can one really hurl slanders when the good man James happens to be uber generous with piling on all the fixins, costarring tasty aiolis and pickled veggies, for less than $8 each?  Damn son.

Yes, in some cases, but mildly so.  While near impossible, particularly when they all come dressed in oops-left-it-in-the-toaster-too-long Acme ciabatta rolls, I brace my gums and the roof of my mouth and stare into the monstrosity to face the challenge of taking a perfectly cross-sectional bite head on. 

Honestly, good stuff and good people behind the counters; sometimes the stars just aren't aligned. Next time.
author: Irene S.

description:
Call in your order for: Vegetarian BBQ sandwich- medium spicy.  Then grab a bag of salt & pepper kettle chips when you pick it up and pay.

And on a sunny day take your amazing sandwich and your amazing self over to Dolores Park for the perfect afternoon.

You will be so glad you did.
author: Marn E.

description: I just started cheating on Deli Board with Rhea's....ummm, these guys are good.  Still love Deli Board but Rhea's has some amazing sando's that have local and asian influences that are a nice change from your typical deli sandwiches.  Top sandwiches for me in this order are the Korean Steak, Gargamel & the Dolores.  The marinate on the steak (korean) and chicken (gargamel) are great.  I could take the meats out and eat them with rice...because that's what I want to do with all good meats...I'm filipino.
author: Ramon L.

description:
I'm a fan of the Korean BBQ sandwich!

I came here with a girlfriend who is Korean.  She told me there was no such thing as a Korean BBQ sandwich in Korea, however it makes sense to make a sandwich out of something that tastes so good.  

I love that the sandwich doesn't rely too heavily on sauce to mask the taste of the fresh ingredients.  The sandwich is pretty big, flavorful and spicy hot.  There's a lot of grilled BBQ meat in the sandwich, but it didn't leave me feeling disgustingly full.  I was full, yet felt like I ate healthily.  

If you stop here I also recommend trying the homemade kimchee.  Better than my mom's homemade kimchee (which was previously my fave) and much better than any jarred kimchee you buy in the store.
author: michele g.

description:
I came here to try their Korean steak sandwich and realized that I've been here once before to get a drink with A. My thoughts then: "Hmm. Typical corner store. Huh, people seem to be lining up for their sandwiches. :::peers at menu::: Who pays $10 for a sandwich?! No thank you."

Ah yelp, how you change my tune. I came here Saturday around 7:30pm and they were out of Korean steak sandwiches. Sad face. A's nice and ordered a sandwich anyway. On the recommendation of the guy behind the counter (hi, nice guy!), A got the roast beef sandwich. To be honest, I thought it was just another sandwich. A says you can't appreciate a really good sandwich unless you've had really bad ones; I've been spoiled by SF. A loved it. Every bite was punctuated by a moan of appreciation. The mustard, the beef, the bread, oh! It's one of the best sandwiches he's ever had. 

We came back the next afternoon so I could try the Korean steak sandwich. I'm single-minded when it comes to food: I want, I get. Apparently I got the last one of the day, score!  The steak is slightly sweet (like Korean BBQ I'm used to) and yummy; medium spiciness was perfect. Worth the $8? Yes. Would I get it every week? Not really. I talked briefly with another customer. She gets their pork katsu sandwich 2-3x/week!  

There's counter seating: 3 tall stools and 2 short stools.  Maybe it's because of A and he's got the gift of gab, but the counter people are really nice. I haven't figured out who to order from, the person by the cash register or the sandwich makers, and I did both. You may need to wait to place your order and wait for your sandwiches, but it's worth it. Cash only.

In SHORT, $10 sandwiches that may trigger an O-moment, hidden in a liquor store. 3.5 stars rounded up.
author: Yan E.

description: Best. Tuna. Salad. Sammich. Ever.
author: Tiffany V.

description: My coworker's recs and Check Please Bay Area have aligned and I got to try Rhea's, now that I work in the Mission. I had a Church St with fake chicken. It was amazing. I totally recommend. Also, call in first before heading over, it's a time-saver.
author: Emily M.

description:
Hands down, best sandwich in the Mission!

Even if Rhea's wasn't a hop, skip and a jump away from my house, I'd travel far to get it. With something for everyone, Rhea's serves-up amazing veggie, vegan and meat lovers options on Acme bread with fancy cheeses, homemade aiolis, spicy spreads and more.

A little something from the deli counter at Rheas + the park = ideal Saturday. 

TIPS FROM DA' WISE: (1) Order ahead and skip the lines. (2) They deliver for FREE in the Mission before 7pm!
author: Nicole d.

description: This is my favorite and go-to deli in the city. The sandwiches are all very creative combinations, fresh ingredients, and made with care. They use Boars Head cold cuts which is a huge plus for me. The Van Ness and Valencia St are my favorites. The Korean steak is also great and very popular. My only drawback to this place is that they can be slow to make sandwiches, are not open long hours, and can be hectic / long line in there. I prefer to call ahead so you dont have to wait there. Overall delicious sammies. Free delivery too!
author: John F.

description:
For when you don't want to wait a million hours for an epic sandwich (not-so-veiled reference to a certain popular SF sandwich shop)-- go to Rheas.  Their sandwiches are really top notch. The Korean steak is definitely the highlight.  House pickled onions, yummy jalapenos, just the right balance between spicy and cheesy and salty and sweet.  Katsu pork isn't too shabby either.  Have yet to try the tacos, but they're def. on my radar.

The guys who work here are SO nice.  So nice in fact, that my dog basically dislocates my shoulder whenever we walk by because she wants to go in and get petted.  Lucky for her, we're here often.  We've gotten into the habit of calling ahead to order a sandwich, although the wait is never more than 5-7 minutes.  Their beer selection is excellent-- decent wine choices too for bringing something to a dinner party.  Or screw the dinner party-- get a bottle of wine to go with your steak sandwich and enjoy it on your couch like the true slob you (and I) are.
author: Kristin P.

description:
So I was craving a sandwich. A good one. A fancy one. I stopped in at La Tartine, took one look at the prices and, clearing my throat, backed out of there awkwardly.

I kept walking, hoping to chance upon something. I walked right past Rhea's because it is disguised as trashy. Honestly, I don't think I even processed that I walked by it. I walked into some bookstore that advertised "light eats." No sandwiches, but they recommend I walk back here. I was skeptical, but I walked in.

What do I see on the menu but a "Tartine Panini." For 2/3 the price of La Tartine. Ha!

Amazing. Crunchy. Quality. Tasty. 

Five fuckin stars, Rhea's. Tou-fucking-che!
author: Sasha W.

description:
Gone-Ta-Rheas: That itching sensation is your impatience.

I went here having heard about great sandwiches on my way to Delores with some friends.  We ordered our sandwiches and had paid when the cashier said to me, I poop you not, "Oh, by the way, it's going to be 45 min, unless that ruins your life," cocking her head to the side at the last bit.  Now, I live in the Mission, so I'm used to good food and terrible service, and I was willing to consider the 45 min, but I thought this was a little far.  However, before I could respond, my friend said that was fine so I held my tongue and off we went to the park.

1 hour and 15 min later, they finally call us, and an hour and a half after I ordered my sandwich I was holding it in my hand.  I ordered a hot sandwich, as you may have guessed, it was now cold.  The sandwich itself shed no light on the mystery of what on earth took so long to make it.  It consists of: meat, cheese, bread, a little bit of pickled vegetables, and some sort of spread.  I had no desire to eat it at this point, but I took one large bite with all the ingredients to get a feel for the taste.  The bread was very hard as bread will get if you toast it and then let it get cold, the sparse ingredients seemed decent in quality. 

More on the 1:15 of wait-time: there were two other people in the shop, milling around, when we were ordering.   I had no reason to believe that they had already ordered.  There was nobody hanging around outside, as people do at this place.  They apparently take a lot of phone orders; I suspect that they give these priority over the suckers who foolishly come into their physical store.

Seriously, there is no reason to go here, Clare's Deli is delicious and only a couple blocks away.  Ike's is amazing and within easy walking distance.  Bump yourself up off of the Rhea's wall and get yourself some sandwich now.
author: Harlen W.

description:
Found this place through SF Weekly. Had a hard time believing that there was a Korean deli in the MIssion. Bummed that I didn't Yelp it first or I would've known to get a bottle of their kimchee. I didn't even notice that they had kimchee today since I was busy anticipating their Korean sandwich!

It takes awhile for them to make (about 15 minutes) but I didn't mind since I wasn't in a rush. I love sandwiches. I love bulgogi. I love spicy sauces. This was heaven! The sandwich is quite filling but not to the point where I was uncomfortably stuffed. 

Next time I will try the Korean tacos and definitely remember to buy a bottle of kimchee!
author: Connie W.

description:
Rhea's is pretty good. For a while, I dismissed this as just another corner store-with-a-deli type of spot. I took a little journey from downtown on BART to come for some sandwiches. And, damn, that was worth the trip.

The Pork Katsu has all kinds of delicious and crunchy spices and vegetables.
Even the "hot" spice level isn't all that hot.

Good sandwiches in the middle of a corner convenience store, so there's tons of drinks and snacks to have on the side.
I'll be coming back.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
You know on TV shows where there is a sandwich that is so wonderful people will do anything to get it, and comedy ensues?  The Korean BBQ sandwich at Rhea's is one of those sandwiches.  It's so wonderful, I haven't gotten to anything else, but that rates Rhea's a 5 stars alone, it is so go.

Also, the people are fantastic!  They are very friendly, and make your feel welcome.  I loved coming here before they opened the deli, and I'm glad such a nice store had such a wonderful idea.

Also, they deliver!  Also, they take cards!  And they sell some excellent Kim Chi.

The only thing is they take a long time to make a sandwich (around 15 minutes), so be prepared to wait, or call ahead (or have it delivered!)
author: C H.

description:
