Before Rhea's Deli, I thought fake chicken was weird. I thank them for showing me how wrong I was with their awesome faux BBQ chicken sammie.

HOWEVER. I hate to say it, vegetarians, but you are missing out by not trying their pork katsu. I'd pork that piggy all night and then cook it breakfast in the morning. Rise and swine!
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Damn tasty sammiches!  Too bad they take so long to make.
All this really means is that I probably need to learn to order in advance, so I don't end up standing around for 20 minutes or so.

They've got a good selection of corner-store basics - wine, booze, snacks, non-booze-beverages, etc.  But you're here for the deli.

The specialty sandwiches are mostly around $8, and completely worth it.  Lots of fun, tasty combinations and quality ingredients make for a great sandwich.  Looking for something more interesting than your usual boring ham & swiss?  Rhea's is your ticket to ride.

They also sell home-made kimchee in mason jars.  Good stuff, though not quite as strongly flavored as I'm used to.
author: Don H.

description:
Rhea's Deli sandwiches are probably my favorite in the city! The ingredients and bread are top notch! My favorite is the Korean Beef, but the Katsu is a close second.

The guys that work there are no nonsense, but friendly whether you call in or walk in. I haven't tried the delivery, but I am tempted to.

The deli is unassuming and I probably walked by it a million times before I ever checked it out. Don't be fooled: everything they carry is high quality and I recommend Rhea's for all your fancypants picnic items. Sea salt potato chips, wine, sparkling water... they have it!
author: Merrill S.

description:
Seems that the trend these days is to slap some type of Korean meat into a taco, burrito, sandwich, etc. and instant fame is awarded. I wasn't sure if I could classify Rhea's in the same category, but after I tried their Korean Steak sandwich, I know that they are NOT like everyone else, and they've got a real good thing going.

They've got a great menu, boasting Boar's Head deli meats (yum, but why do they have to be so expensive??) and Tartine bread. I'm sure those ingredients would go well on a build-your-own sandwich, but really, this Korean steak sandwich is where its at. Marinated beef, shredded lettuce, pickled veggies and some spicy, possibly Kimchee inspired spread, and cheddar cheese all wrapped up in a roll. That's goodness you shouldn't mess with. Thumbs up for Rhea's and their yummy creation.
author: Christina N.

description:
I'm not sure if I'm pathetic for wanting to come in just to hang out with the people that work here (even on Saturday night), or if they are just that cool. I'm going to go with the latter. James, Jesse, and George (apparently you can't work here unless your name starts with a "juh") are so incredibly friendly and just plain cool that I make sure to pop in whenever I walk by. Which is daily.
 
It is so nice to live in an area where at least 1 person knows your name. I'm not asking for the Cheers bar or something, I don't need EVERYBODY to know my name, but just that 1 person makes me feel special - like this is my neighborhood. Aw shucks now I'm getting all warm and fuzzy inside...

Also, chances are if I'm in desperate need of something, they have it. Well, maybe they don't have something like wild mushrooms or anchovies (cause lord knows I'm desperate for those all the time), but certainly anything relatively straight forward they can handle. For example, they have soy milk stocked all the time, which earns big points in my book.

They just remodeled and opened a cheese counter and deli, which is dangerous for me as I now see my sandwich intake increasing three-fold in the coming weeks. And they aren't messin' around with their ingredients - cowgirl creamery cheese and acme bread baby, only the best at this corner store!

If you're in the area and need some cash, candy, a cold beer, or some great conversation, Rhea's has got everything you need.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Came for the Korean steak sandwich as I am on a quest to eat the 20 epic sandwiches on sf.eater before I die. This sandwich was amazing I got it 'very spicy' but didn't really notice much heat after the first bite; just a lot of deliciousness and a satisfied feeling in my belly about 2 minutes later once it was finished. Took about 15 mins for them to make it but it was worth the wait. Get it.
author: James D.

description:
I live around the corner.  I come probably about one to three times a month.  On par with BITE in lower nob hill.  

++++++
- locally owned by James, your awesome local neighborhood liquor store owner.
- sandwiches are particularly amazing.
- you can call in your order.
- the korean beef is ridiculously good.
- non-pretentious and delicious.

- - - - - - 
- takes ten to fifteen minutes because it's so good, so call ahead.
- prices are about $1 too high.
- they close early (wish they were open later than they are).

Overall, James and George are my favorites and I'm glad that I live next to such a wonderful neighborhood shop.

I'll be in for "27s" soon.
author: Mo J.

description: Korean steak (bulgogi) sandwich was on point, but it took a long ass time to produce (30 minutes).
author: Kevin L.

description:
I'm one of the guilty parties that has only ever tried the Korean beef sandwich. It's delicious! I keep meaning to try something else, but why mess with perfection? 

Definitely listen to the folks who tell you to call ahead. You could waste your whole lunch hour waiting for them to craft your tasty sub if you order on arrival. 

Aside from their speciality, this place is an above average corner shop with a decent looking deli counter and a wine selection that's not too shabby. And the folks working there are pretty nice too.
author: Cec C.

description:
The Ike's killer? Maybe.

It speaks to the dearth of good sandwich shops in this city that making a halfway decent one makes people FLOCK. That said Rhea's sandwiches are excellent. It does take a while to get your sandwich and (speaking for my family) their menu could do with a bunch more veggie options but credit where credit is due: the pork katsu and korean steak sandwiches being where it is due!

The dudes there are super-nice. I have nothing else to say...that's it...uh...GRR!!! Why were you guys closed for cleaning on Monday?!?! Surely that wasn't necessary. :/

Minor criticisms aside, kudos to Rhea's for offering an option. Maybe one day we'll have...3 good sandwich shops in the Mission?
author: Alee K.

description: Had the korean steak sando. too legit to quit. might be a weekly stop for a while.
author: Raekwon D.

description: This local sandwhich spot is on point! The Buster Posey is so meaty and delicious! I would call ahead because they always have a long line out the door! They also have healthy options :)
author: Siobhan R.

description: You can't make these sandwiches at home.  We tried the Korean and the Veggie Steak.  Both were fantastic.  I will definitely be back!
author: Kristin P.

description: I was ruined by Washington DC corner stores, which are not cool. Here, I bought detergent, and realized -- much to my delight -- that they get their sandwich ON here, hard-core. Like a corner store sells Korean-influenced sandwiches and tonkatsu. And, they sell like Cowboy Creamery cheese. And Kombucha. Sensory overload!
author: Andrew K.

description: Awesome Korean BBQ sandwich!  Portions are a little small, but the bread is delicious and the sandwich is good.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Recently gave this place another shot at the begging of a friend, VERY glad I did. I ordered the same thing, just to make sure what I was delivered was, indeed, an old, gross sandie. Sure enough, it was brilliant when it wasn't a thousand hours old! Very tasty, and a nice alternative to the familiar "meat-cheese-condiment" option.

$10 for delivery, they will deliver anything in the store - awesome. Only took them about 30 minutes this time, I'll be back :)
author: Natalie S.

description:
Grungy on the outside is gourmet on the inside. One of my addictions is cigarettes...I can get those there. My second addiction is the Valencia Street Sandwich, which I can't get anywhere else in the world. Rhea's figured out what people really wanted - fresh, quality, varied ingredients in their sandwiches, and the convenience of grabbing a 6-pack of PBR or a pair of cheap sunglasses while you're at it.

I work down the street and often have them deliver by bicycle - sandwich is always still hot, and so are the boys that bring it to me...just sayin'.
author: Leslie F.

description:
It's one of those "who knew?" kind of places. The whole year-plus I've lived in this area, I've walked by this place, dismissing it as just another one of several convenience stores around here.

The advantage of getting sandwiches in a group is you get to try different ones. So, I had a ham tartine panini, which was awesome. Love the cheese-infused bread due to the sammie being hot-pressed. Also got to try the katsu (also awesome) and a decent turkey bacon (in my experience, it's rare that you get crispy bacon in a sandwich--Rhea's passes!). Will be back for sure...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I've been a pretty consistent weekend customer since the beginning of 09 when one of my besties moved into the building above. Rhea's may be the very reason, in fact, that I started to like beer (nice beer, that is- like chimay- because they have it, and a lot of corner stores don't). Well, now i live in the building too!! And guess what- now they have a deli~! how perfect is that. James knows how to put together a legit vegetarian sandwich, an art form which has been honed by very few, haha! 

Anyways, weekend trips to Rhea's are now turning into nightly trips. 

And, on behalf of the residents of #206 and #207, I would like to say thank you to Jesse & James for treating us like respectable human beings, even when we showed up in, uh...slightly altered states, let's just say... from time to time :) Thanks! Love you guys! See you tonight!
author: Shannon R.

description: Was told to check this sandwich place out. Went on a Sunday and was fortunate to find parking because was previously advised that parking was terrible. Ordered the popular sandwich-the Korean BBQ sandwich. You walk in to the deli, they have a sheet you fill out to make your order, pay and wait til your name gets called. The sandwich was of typical size, my boyfriend and I split it since based on the previous reviews was given the impression that it was a huge sandwich, but I think we both have good appetites and should have ordered another sandwich. The Korean BBQ sandwich was pretty tasty, the beef was tender, you had a choice of cheese to choose from, and the pickled veggies were good. The only thing is I wish they could put some kimchi for extra kick in the sandwich, so it could tie in all the flavors.
author: Sheena L.

description:
I've only had one sandwich here so far, the Korean Steak, but I can say it's my favorite sammie in the city. Damn is it good! I walked in and the guy asked if I was hungry. Hells yah! I briefly perused the menu, and he suggested getting the korean steak, which he had just finished making for himself, and said it was the best one. I went with all of his suggestions for the sammie, and it was divine. All of the ingredients work very well together. I could only eat half so I saved the rest for the next day. I could barely wait til lunch time to tear into the second half.

My boy just got the katsu (he's not a cow lovah), and he agrees that Rhea makes the best sammies in SF!.
author: Cara H.

description:
Got the Korean steak sandwich.  Pretty good.  I like the concept but they could work on the customer service.  Stood in front of the deli counter for a while and the sandwich guy just ignored me.  Finally went up to the cashier and asked where I ordered and he took my order (then I saw the sandwich guy ask the guy behind me if he needed to order so it wasn't like the cashier always takes orders).  Thirty-five minutes later, yes *35* minutes later, I got my sandwich.  If it's going to take that long, you would think they'd give a heads up.  At least I'd have been able to bring my copy of War and Peace and finished it by the time I got my lukewarm sandwich.  Sammy was tasty, but  too sweet. 

Also docked a star since I was sitting outside, they saw me waiting for over half an hour, they knew I was waiting since I asked about it 10 minutes before, and they didn't even call my name!  It was only when the guy behind me got called that I asked about my sandwich and then they say, "Oh, you're sandwich is ready, it's up at the counter"  WTF?!  Yeah, I'll probably stick to Ike's 'cause at least they have a SYSTEM.   
Suggestions: put a sign up next to the cashier saying "Order sandwiches here" and make sure the cashier says how long the wait is.  If the cashier has to stock inventory in the cold cases, don't let him do it when there are customers in the store since people were waiting around wondering why they have to wait 5 minutes to buy a pack of cigarettes when there were so many people waiting and no one behind the register.  That way introverted sandwich guy can focus on making the sandwiches and put out more than 1 every 15 minutes.  And you may want more than 1 person making sandwiches during lunch hour.  I'm sure my sandwich would've tasted better if I didn't have the bitter taste of bad service in my mouth.
author: kiwi l.

description: The reviews didn't lie. I had the korean steak sammy and it was about the best sandwich I have had in SF. I am dying to try the pork Katsu sammy (maybe tomorrow even).  The owner was there talking to someone about how he pounds the cutlets every night and it makes his arms sore (he said about 10 qty of them takes him about a 1/2 hour) . All the workers were super friendly, and concerned about everyone's order.  The place seems nice and clean (especially for the mission).  If this weren't so far away from my neighborhood I could see being a bi-(or tri) weekly regular.
author: Amy W.

description:
These guys are SO incredibly friendly every time I stop in.  Best corner store ever.

And they sell Bandit, that wine that comes in the Euro-style boxes.  And they're about to have sandwiches (can't wait)!
author: Nathan F.

description:
Yeah, holy shit. San Francisco, how do you continue to produce such amazing sandwich joints? (I never use the word joint.)

I tried the Van Ness. The person at the register called it the "Boom Jiggles" because that's supposedly what happens to your stomach after eating it. I'd take my chances on it over and over and over again.

If I lived closer, I would try a new sandwich everyday until I decided I had a favorite one. And if I couldn't decide after tasting every sandwich, I'd try each sandwich again all over again.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Amazing bbq veggie chicken sandwich!  I would have never known, if not for Yelp!  Thank you, Yelp!

Their sandwich counter hours are not the same as their store hours, though.  I think they stop making sandwiches at about 8 each night.  

The only hitch was that I had to wait 30 minutes for my sandwich.  But it was pleasant to wait on their bench outside in the sun today.  A woman passed, and called to her dog, "Here, Buddha!"  WTF!  #dognamefail !
author: Ravi C.

description:
I always thought that I would be compelled to write my first Yelp review out of retaliation at some business that had royally pissed me off. And I have almost penned one about a couple of places in my neighborhood a couple of times. However, I am happy to report that my first Yelp review is about something that I love. 

My dog, Turtle, and I always used to pass Rhea's Deli on our walk. Turtle loved popping in because they have treats behind the counter and everyone that works there was so nice. Then in the last few months they put in a deli and started selling sandwiches. I am now obsessed and finally have a new cheap lunch option in the neighborhood. These are the reasons that their sandwiches are amazing:

1. The bread is either from Acme or Tartine (and you don't have to wait in Tartine's line or pay Tartine's prices). Oh, and they have normal bread too.

2. The Aiolis: If there was a way to bold this on a Yelp review I would. I hate mayonnaise. I think it is disgusting. However, their aiolis are amazing. This could be because they make them FRESH throwing the olive oil, egg, and garlic or whatever other flavors into the food processor daily or a few times a day. Yum. Seriously, this makes all the difference.

3. The pickled onions. James, the owner, pickles red onions himself. Again, yum. And he does it simply with champagne vinegar, a little sugar and maybe one other thing-- I forget. Point is I have fresh, homemade pickled onions on my sandwich. This is no extra charge. They also have pickled jalapeños; I haven't tried those yet.

4. All the ingredients are top. All the prices are not. I do not see why you would go to Bi-Rite over Rheas. It makes no sense. 

5. They are really flexible. I bet I could ask them to do something super annoying to my sandwich like toast one half of the bread and not the other and they would be like, no problem, glad to do it. 

So point is that it is the place to get the sandwich. My sister lives in cow hollow. She had a sandwich from here. She thought it was so amazing, she said she is going to have to start driving over to my neighborhood expressly to go to Rheas. They have cow girl creamery cheese, a panini press, and basically anything else an amazing sandwich shop would want. Ok, that is my first Yelp review.
author: Liz M.

description:
I was really upset the first time I had the Korean steak sandwich. I couldn't believe my mother made me bulgogi all these years and never thought to produce it in sandwich form herself. 

The bread's perfectly crunchy AND soft, the onions add just the right amount of oomph to the perfectly marinated meat, and the sauce is the kind that burns in your tummy for a while afterwards, but in a good way. But to echo other reviewers, get the mild. I'm pretty snobby/arrogant about my spicy tolerance, but I definitely had to pause halfway through my "medium" spicy sandwich. The sandwich has plenty of flavor, regardless of spicy level. 

My only wish is that they'd stay open later on weekdays, so I can treat myself to an amazing sandwich after work...
author: Christie C.

description: It's true, the guy with the beard is simply the best.   He made me an amazing steak sandwich, and when I was done, I went to ride home--but my bike had a flat.  Always the worst!  I went inside to ask about a nearby bike shop, but Beard Dude just happened to have a pump on hand.  Lucked out this time! Rhea's rules!  Thanks beard guy.
author: x x.

description:
Reasons for liking Rheas sandwiches (in contrast to another popular Mission sandwich place):
- Efficient call ahead ordering
- Sandwich ready in 10 minutes
- Friendly and fast service
- Sandwich does not turn into soggy, goopy mess on the 10 minute walk home
- Sandwich is in fact delicious

Only wish they had more veggie options.
author: Prasad G.

description: They make the best sandwiches around here. They even carry Leffe beer, which you should totally try if you haven't. You will stop drinking PBR afterwards.
author: Florian J.

description:
Excellent Veggie BBQ chicken sandwich. I used to eat a lot of vietnamese sandwiches, but this one is my favorite. I will sometimes drive 30 minutes across town for Rhea's sandwiches! 
The service is pretty friendly too!
author: Rahul A.

description:
Man, these are some good sandwiches.  Every time I spend time at Valencia, I want one of those sandwiches.

Thinking about it makes me hungry!!!
author: Andy W.

description:
James does make a mean sandwich, that's for damned sure!  I don't believe there's another deli counter within a mile that can boast having Tartine bread and Cowgirl Creamery cheeses... so there!

I love this market! I must confess that I'm a bit biased here, I lived across the street for years... and now I walk 20 minutes just to see James, buy beer, and hear stories about what his son is doing now.
author: Andy S.

description:
Did you say you want to take me out for dinner, honey? Yes! Great! Where are we going? Limon? Maverick? Beretta? Nope... Rhea's Deli!
What? Ok. So I Yelped this place and to my surprise, all stars!! Okay lets go now for some sandwiches. No one would guess they had a little deli counter in the back inside a corner liquor market. I ordered the Valencia w/ turkey and havarti. My hubbie had the Cunningham w/ salami and cheddar. Mine was perfect. His on the otherhand was too oily due to the fact the sandwich was toasted and the cheddar melted. Otherwise, both was nicely done especially the red onions and the garlic spread. Definitely be back again to try their famous Korean Steak Sandwich,
author: Mauling W.

description:
So i got a $61 korean steak sandwich here last saturday - $8 for the sandwich and $53 for the expired meter ticket (thank you DPT!)

My bad, i didn't think it would take longer than 20 mins to get my sandwich, delicious as it was.  But my bout of begging the meter maid not to give me a ticket didn't sour me on Rhea's deli.  Next time I'll just use the the free delivery - with $10 minimum, it'll just mean that i have to get BOTH a korean steak sandwich and chicken katsu sandwich.(or maybe throw some beer, chips, candy, etc in there
author: Jules L.

description:
MMMMMMMmmmmmm! Thank you fellow Yelpers for turning us on to this hole in the wall deli inside a liquor store. The dude making the sandwiches took his time and carefully made us two of the best we have ever had. No joking. It was that good! I had the Korean Steak Sandwich and Wifey had the Portabella Mushroom Sandwich. Liberal use of spicy spreads gave the eats a glow that enhanced the other flavors. ...The bread was fresh!

We ate at the the place two nights in a row while visiting the city. The second night - they were out of the Korean Steak which was a real bummer. That is the only reason why I didn't give it five stars.
author: Star G.

description:
The Korean Steak sandwich is super good! Maybe it was the fact that I was crazy starving and could barely wait to eat this when I got home, this is well worth the $8.50. I got the mild version and it totally was mild. I hate when it's too spicy and I'm not in the mood to have my mouth on fire. 

When you get there, go to the deli counter and grab a little piece of paper that will let you mark up what you want on your sandwich. After that give it to the cashier and then they'll hand it to the sandwich counter.

Went around 1:30 on a Friday and the wait wasn't bad, about 10-15 minutes. Not a problem I wandered over to Paxton Gate to browse.

Bare bones little liquor shop. Other than the deli there's nothing to make you go there unless you need to load up on libations.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I got the Korean Steak sandwich as it was perfectly seasoned and absolutely delicious. I originally requested it to be medium spicy but the guy taking my order asked if it was my first time (it was) and said I should try mild first. I still think I would have been able to handle the medium, but I was thankful he was being so conscientious. 

The wait was a bit long and they did warn me beforehand (10-15 minutes) on a rainy Saturday afternoon. The guy at the counter also took pity on me and let me use my last remaining $1 to buy an Aero chocolate bar (usually $2).
author: Anna Y.

description:
I have gone their twice, but I'm a fan already. When I order spicy hot, I get wonderfully spicy hot. Not "eyes watering hot" (which is nice), but lip tingling / full mouth tingling hot. 

I was surprised not to see them come up on lunch spots in my 'hood. I had to have a friend tell me about them before I tried. I pass the place all the time between home and work, and the place only looked good for buying PBR. It seems to fit that role as well, oddly enough. 

Like everyone else says, they serve on ACME bread and have all the right fixings. The fresh kimchi is amazing.
author: Benjamin T.

description: This place is the shit. I use to go to Rhea's for multiple things as I was an intern at one point in time. They pretty much stock up on everything that you desire within the quaint confines. Whether it's a bottle of OE to a pack of Parliaments, they'll have it. But what Rhea's is really infamous for are their Korean BBQ sandwiches. It's the shit. One bite and you'll scarf it down in no time flat. Ask for it extra spicy and you're taste buds will either thank you or hate you. Either way you'll definitely be coming back for more.
author: Elijah A.

description: Hmm, good. Great sandwiches and service. Korean steak, pork katsu, pastrami...it's all great!
author: Peg W.

description:
I found this place on Yelp when I was looking for some Korean-fusion inspired fare in Frisco.  I had the Bulgogi Sandwich - excellent.  I liked the flavors and the housemade pickled jalapenos were a nice addition.  

I also the thought the bread was perfect for the sandwich - toasted, fresh, and matched the meat perfectly.  

The owner, James, was very cool.  He was gracious enough to share his thoughts on the restaurant biz, Korean food, etc!    

I'm going to try the Katsu when I go back to Frisco next time!
author: Peater J.

description: Excellent Ritter Sport selection, and you sell the Canadian cigarettes I like. I love this place!
author: Ian A.

description:
Big props to Rhea's for coming up with some unique sandwiches. Always refreshing to have something new. I couldn't help but wonder where all the Asian influence came from when it was two Mexicans and a white guy working there. Maybe it's a Korean owned shop. Anyway... 

On to the sandwiches, we had the Korean BBQ ($8.45) sandwich and the Chicken Katsu ($7.95), both were spicy but the Katsu one took it to a whole another level. I personally couldn't get through the entire sandwich without some type of drink. The cabbage was a little bitter too, which was weird. The Korean BBQ sandwich had much more flavor, less spicy, and much more enjoyable on the taste buds. 

I would definitely go back to try some of there other stuff, only if I'm around the area. If you are trying to grab a quick sandwich, the parking situation is terrible. Just have a buddy drive and drop you off while they circle around. If you do decide to stay, there is a nice huge window you can sit in front of to people watch while you eat.
author: Andrew C.

description: The vege-steak sandwich is UNHOLY in its deliciousness. I mean this. It is the best sandwich I've ever had, and I want them to never, ever, ever stop making it. Do you hear me, Rhea's?
author: heather c.

description: All of the sandwiches I tried here are really good. Sometimes you might have to wait for 20 or 30 minutes just to get it, but it's worth it. If going during peak times, plan on waiting. Easy to kill time by walking around for a few.
author: J K.

description: I find myself here more often than I want and pretty much always leave dissatisfied. Their dutch crunch bread is amazing and the sandwich quality is decent but the wait is always at least 15 minutes, the sandwiches feel like their quality has decreased significantly over time, at least in part because it feels like they don't really heat up their sandwiches that much. It is simply not worth awkward standing around the counter until your sandwich is ready.
author: Ojus P.

description:
if you've read any of my other reviews, you'll know i love sandwiches. here's another GREAT spot for a fantastic sandwich. 

if you're going in the middle of the day and only have an hour lunch break, you might consider giving them a call before you go. then take your sammie down to dolores and enjoy this fucking gorgeous weather we've been having lately. now that's a spectacular lunch.
author: Georgia W.

description: Only been here once... sunday around lunch time... luckily not too busy so no wait... I really wanted the pork katsu sandwich, but they said they don't make it anymore... not sure, but they said they're either expanding their kitchen or building another location somewhere?  If i'm making that up, sorry.  Anyway, I got the BBQ veggie "chicken" sandwich... it was very good... very nicely assembled.. bread was crisp and flaky on the outside, but soft on the inside... perfect.. good proportions of everything.. good flavor... I'll be back here to try some other sandwiches... just didn't feel like a big meaty one this time..
author: Easter E.

description:
I pass this place almost every day on my walk to work and on my way home again. After reading the sign advertising the vegetarian steak sandwich for the umpteenth time, I stopped in on a hungry walk home one Friday evening to see what the fuss was about. Well, I still don't know what the fuss is about, 'cause after perusing the menu, I decided to get the veggie bbq "chicken" sandwich instead -- and oh my goodness. I daydream about this sandwich. Astonishingly delicious marinated "chicken," lots of veggies, some kind of spicy aioli... I don't even care, I just know it tastes amazing. One of these days I will have to try the veggie steak sandwich, but I am not sure how it could beat this one.

I don't get off work until 5:30 and I really wish Rhea's was open 'til 6 on weekdays. I've bought a sandwich for lunch a couple of times, but they're kind of messy and I'm usually in a rush. 

The service is usually pretty efficient. I've never had to wait too long, but that could be lucky timing. Ordering in advance by phone seems to be the way to go if you don't want to wait.

One time I left work late and came in right after 6 on a Friday, when they were just closing up the deli. The guy working the counter saw my disappointment and was really sweet -- agreed to make me a sandwich even though he was about to leave. I spent a few minutes chatting with the cashier, and I walked out with my sandwich feeling great, mouth watering. Made my whole evening.
author: Stacia T.

description: My first meal in San Francisco was the Valencia Street sandwich. Absolutely amazing! Must go there.
author: Sabrina J.

description:
YES! Finally a deli that deserves to call itself a Deli! Their sandwiches are delicious and fresh. The guys who work there are always nice and joking around. Everything from their signature Veggie chicken Sandwich to their bacon filled Valencia sammy are spectacular. 

I am double stoked about being able to call in and order my sandwich ahead of time so I can bypass the 20 minute wait outside. Love this place!
author: Didi R.

description: $9 plus change for a sandwich on a itty bitty little roll! Give me a break, it ain't even as good as reviewed. as for the kim chee, it's production line made, it comes out of a jar that's made locally, i thought i recognized the jar as one of the local 5 star hotels buys the same stuff! It ain't homemade! These 2 clerks have no idea what customer service means! it wasn't busy yet, 5 sandwiches came out before i got mine & i had to ask. $9, i expect it to feed 2 people, what a joke! shows you that their kim chee tastes like her ancient korean recepie, what production made recepie?NOT going back there, what a rip off! go somewhere where you have a choice of size, this place one sizeonly like it or not! Nowhere on their sign states what the size of the sandwich is. BUYER BEWARE!
author: david c.

description:
Like most fellow yelpers, I've ventured to Ike's and Bakesale Betty's in Oakland for their sandwiches. Yes, I will drive all over town for good food.  So, when I heard about a Korean BBQ sandwich out there...well, off I went. Mad Mochi was on a mission! 

Ordered the BBQ sandwich & chicken cutlet sandwich. Prices weren't too bad about $7 to $8 and the sandwiches were a decent size. I was able to split the sandwiches with a friend and we both agreed the BBQ sandwich is the one to get. We had mild sauce slathered on it and it brought just enough heat to make your taste buds go "OoooH!" The meat was definitely tasty and you could taste the Korean marinade. Wished there was a little more meat but it was still all good. Couldn't help but wonder if cheese over Korean beef was a mistake but ya know what? Damn it, it worked! 

The sandwich had a nice crunch. Had to put that in cause my friend kept raving about how she like the bread and how it was perfectly toasted. Loved the veggies that were nicely layered in the sandwich; it also added to the crunch factor of the sandwich. I would definitely go back for this one. Wonder if Rhea will eventually do a BBQ Chicken Korean sandwich? Now that would be hella good!!! (Rhea if you're reading...hint hint =).... 

Ok enough of me salivating over the BBQ sandwich. Onward to the chicken cutlet. After my first bite, the thought that hit me was this looks and kind of tastes like a Bakesale Betty's chicken sandwich. There was cabbage slaw over a peppery fried chicken nestled between toasted bread. 

However, I was quickly brought back to reality when the hot sauce hit my senses and sent me reaching for my Coke Zero. Mad Mochi's taste buds were on fire.  For whatever reason, the hot sauce was a wee-bit heavy on this sandwich. Definitely it was still good - the chicken wasn't dry nor greasy and it was seasoned just right. Very flavorful and spicy. It's the Asian version of Bakesale Betty's sandwich. 

In a nutshell - would I go back? You betcha! 

Next time I'm going to try their Korean tacos....=)
author: Cris H.

description:
Just ate their Korean BBQ sammich and pork katsu sammich.
I will be ordering again SOON.

5 delicious starshines!!!
author: Keika L.

description: So I lied, we've been back here more than a handful of times and every time we'd get the same sandwiches (korean bulgogi & katsu) and they've been good every time. I got another sandwiches twice and it was alright, so I guess we're sticking w/ the bulgogi and katsu. My nephew who normally don't like sandwiches. Actually said it was good.
author: Lyd N.

description:
A rather basic selection of groceries, although there is a "deli" (which we didn't try)... BUT the beer selection is surprisingly decent, incl. tons of 22 & 24 oz. choices. Nice, young cashiers; a few fresh fruit choices, but (like the deli) mainly emergencies-only; and rare seating area with stools and prime views of the street.

Overall, an average corner store with some extra umph in the beer department.
author: G. J.

description:
This place is one of the most unassumingly delicious treasures I've been to in a long time.

I got the bbq veg sandwich with the extra hot sauce.  Holy buttonsnaps it was hot.  Bread was great and the staff was funny and friendly.

Grab a bite, and a drink (preferably of the alcoholic persuasion) and head to the park.  The Full House opening won't have shit on this.  Suck it Stamos.
author: C J.

description: Terrific service... fantastic eats. I recommend the turkey on dutch crunch with avocado, tomato, provolone, onions and bacon.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Took me forever to try this place!  I like the fact that you can actually sit down either outside or inside and enjoy your sando immediately.. unlike that place on 16th near Market.
author: Demanding T.

description:
The quality of these sandwiches and the time that goes into them was a very pleasant surprise. I got the vegetarian BBQ chicken which you can get mild, medium or spicy. It was DELICIOUS and the perfect size to split with someone as long as you get some chippys or potato salad to go with it. The cabbage adds a wonderful earthy taste and I always love a little crunch factor. MMMMMM. Everyone who works here is super nice too. 
The store has an impressive collection of old timey candy bars (woot) and an abundance of beer and Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream flavors. What else do you need?
author: Emily S.

description: This is my neighborhood corner store, so one could say I'm a bit biased due to the proximity to my house and availability of items pretty much whenever I need them--but, this is definitely a place I would go out of my way to come to for their amazing VEGETARIAN BBQ CHICKEN SANDWICH! It is so so so good! Fresh slaw, delicious sauce, pretty real chicken (which I don't usually like, but this stuff is CRAMAZING--yes, I did just make up a word)! It's just that good!
author: Shira O.

description: Delicious sandwiches. Lots of choices, and everything is amazing. I would HIGHLY recommend calling your order in ahead of time. Otherwise, be prepared to stand around outside for 45 minutes until your sandwich is ready... (which is what I did the first time I went here).
author: Michelle L.

description:
this place has been on my "bookmarks" for a LONG time. i've always wanted to try the korean steak sandwich but it took me forever to stop in.

 you know how there's the whole korean taco kick going on? every time i eat a korean taco i think to myself "this is great, but i wish i had some rice instead of this corn tortilla." uhhh well that tells me i'd rather be eating at a traditional korean bbq spot rather than having it all mexican fusioned. i thought a korean sandwich might have me feeling the same thing. but when i bit into the sandwich my mind went insane for a little bit! the sweet of the korean beef mixed with the spicy of the aioli and jalapenos, the salty of the sharp cheddar and the fantastic acme bread was amazing! i would take korean beef in a Rhea's sandwich over korean beef with rice any day! SO good. get your hands on one! in fact, get your hands on two and save one for me. we'll go kick it in the park and eat these amazing sandwiches in silence. talking can wait for after the sandwiches. haha!!
author: Regina C.

description:
Rhea's is our favorite corner store in the Mission.  I usually stop by to use the ATM (it is close to the Lex and I never have cash on hand) or to buy a six pack or bottle of wine.

What makes Rhea's my favorite?  The owner -- who usually mans the cash register -- is SO FUN.  He is welcoming, chatty , and equipped with a stellar sense of humor.  I usually leave in a fit of giggles due to his relentlessly funny jokes and general likeability.  

Last time we were there, we all sang along together to Boyz II Men ("Thrrooww yo clothes! On the flooor!").  He said that would be new litmus test for whether one was over 21 years old.  If you knew the lyrics to Boyz II Men, you passed.  He was like, if you were under 21, you would say: "Who is this?  The Temptations?"  and then he would know you were too young for booze.  See?  I love this guy.

Great beer and wine selection too...
author: Sid D.

description:
a liquor store AND great sandwiches?  yes, it is possible.  

i had the korean steak sandwich.  spicy, yummy, tender, tasty.  we also ordered the vegetarian sandwich and the person loved it even though she wasn't vegetarian.  turkey sandwich also got the thumbs up.  is there any sandwich here that isnt liked?
im going to find out.

how come no one told me about the katsu sandwich dammit?  gonna have to go back and get one, and a 40 for my homies.
author: I Be E.

description:
Are you freaking kidding me?? 9/24 2:30 pm we ordered 2 sandwiches, paid and were then told "30 min wait." Came back 30 min later and only the Korean beef sandwich was ready. We had to "wait another 10 min plus" for the corned beef sandwich.  WTF????
There are now 15 plus people waiting for their food and they ALL got served before us.  These knuckleheads do NOT understand business. Some JACK WAGON in their line made a mistake and did not make the 2nd sandwich. MAKE IT NOW!!! What a bunch of imbeciles.  The Korean beef sandwich was VERY cool and the bread mushy by the time the 2nd sandwich was done.  There is no damn good reason to ever eat here again. These fools need to manage the business better or they will lose their locals who come here.  
BTW, we received the faintest apology which lacked sincerity. 
DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME AT THIS PLACE.
author: Suzanne N.

description:
My co-worker called to order 7 sandwiches for the office and was told that they couldn't do 7 sandwiches--not that it would take a little bit longer because it was such a large order, which would be totally understandable--but that they simply couldn't/wouldn't do it. That makes absolutely no sense. George, who picked up the phone at Rhea's, even hung up on my co-worker at one point. 

The sad thing is that we were all very excited to try the food because we'd heard such great things, but now, Rhea's has lost 7 potential customers...and their friends and so on. 

If you can only make 6 sandwiches during the lunch hour, you really shouldn't be in the lunch or the sandwich business, Rhea's. Get your situation figured out.
author: Robin T.

description: Love this sandwich spot. Probably my favorite sandwich place of my life. The bread is delicious, the ingredients are high quality and fresh. I try to get a Rhea's sandwich at least once a week if not more! So gooooood. I have tried quite a few of their sandwiches and like to try something new here and there. Korean Steak, Valencia Street, Noe Street, Judah Street, and 18th Street sandwiches are some of my top choices.
author: Marieke V.

description: I heard from a friend that they are not selling the katsu sandwich anymore?! Wtf?! I went last time and they ran out. Thats the one I wanna try the most. Don't get me wrong. The bul go Gi and other deli sandwiches are good, but this is disappointing to hear. I hope it comes back! I had to write a review just to say this. I bought the kim chee last time and thought it awesome. Better quality than most. It was close to some of the best kimchee I've had from la, NYC, and Korea
author: Bryant L.

description:
Came here on Sunday during the Pride Parade, drove through traffic and spent over 30mins finding street parking. Took the first bite of my Spicy Pork Katsu on Acme bread sandwich and it was worth the trip! In sandwiches, I usually try to avoid the crust but the acme bread's crust was crispy I couldn't get enough of it. Spicy is actually spicy, so don't get spicy if you cannot handle it. All the elements in this sandwich works good together. 

I had some of my girlfriend's Medium Spicy Korean Beef Steak and it was good as well. The beef was tender, flavorful and there wasn't much fat unlike most Bulgogi at a Korean restaurant. The sandwiches can get messy, so don't forget to grab extra napkins. 

This place is definitely on the same level as Ike's, if not better! They have good selection of beers and a counter to eat while you watch people walk-by. What more can you ask on a nice Sunday afternoon?
author: Sam P.

description: I still love you Rhea's - but the quality is hit or miss these days.
author: Stephanie P.

description: One of the best sandwiches in SF I have had. Get the Korean steak sandwich and pack your bags for heaven.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time, I was gushing about how tasty the sandwich was. The second time, the service was crap. One guy dismissively told me I needed to fill out some bullshit bureaucratic form for a sandwich. I guess it would have been too hard for him to check off, "Sandwich," or whatever himself considering I didn't have any preferences about toppings.

It's a shame because the first time I went, I had extremely pleasant service from a woman working there. Now I won't come again.

Also, they don't tell you when you'll be waiting thirty minutes for a sandwich. Guess I wasn't part of their cool hipster clique.
author: adrian b.

description: Hands down best sandwich spot in the mission.  Been to all the others and this place kicks all their asses. No gimmicks, no bells and whistles, just some good meat between bread. James and his crew know what's up and they remember your name, which is more than i can say for some of those other spots. The Valencia, the Pork Katsu, the Lexington, the Cunnignham, the Noe. Call it in and you can pick it up or TCB will deliver it to your spot. Locals know what's up, people that stand in line don't.
author: I D.

description: So underwhelmed by the Korean steak sandwich. Bread was for sure day old. Steak was not tender nor well marinated. Everyone on the jock tip has seriously never had a delicious sandwich with high quality meat and bread.   Over priced for poor quality. If you like big portions this is your joint.
author: L. I. Z.

description: What can I say about Rhea's that hasn't already been said?  I love this place, I would commit a hate crime on anyone that tried to talk some shit about Rhea's in front of me, for reals.  I drive from Solano County for some Rhea's, every weekend.  If my wife was like, "I don't want to drive to San Francisco this weekend, can't we go to a different deli?"  I'd divorce her ass, get alimony and move somewhere closer to Rhea's.
author: Terry H.

description:
Why have I not reviewed this place sooner?

Definitely my favorite corner store.  I live closer to the Golden Eagle end of the block, but will walk that extra half block to go to Rhea's ;) The guys that work the counter are always so friendly.. I don't think they recognize me yet, but we always have a quick and cheery chat when I pick up my munchies or the occasional adult beverage.  They have a pretty good selection of your household necessities too, to hold me off between Safeway/Trader Joe's runs.

Minus one star because they don't do cash back and the ATM charges hella fees (but what ATM doesn't :P).  And I can't remember if they take credit cards.. if they do, they definitely have a minimum.
author: Christie C.

description:
Korean beef sandwich...wow. It's literally a pile of bulgogi on an edible plate (aka, the bread). Imagine one of those massive NY pastrami sandwiches, only the meat is brown and slightly less carcinogenic. And spicy. Ow. Get the mild if you're unsure, discretion is the better part of valor.

Bonus points for the bread, it was surprisingly soft and chewy despite somehow having the structural integrity to keep the sandwich in one piece.
author: Victor L.

description:
Before moving to Oakland, I always stopped at this cornerstore for my beer on the way to Dolores because they've always been so friendly. I was pleased to discover the other day that it's been expanded into a deli. 

Sandwiches are one of my favorite meals. And the best way to impress me at a sandwich counter is have a pad where I can write down exactly what I want. Their original sandwiches all sounded delicious, but I decided to create my favorite. Turkey, Swiss, and avocado on a sweet roll with mayonnaise, mustard, pickles, lettuce, and pickled jalapenos. It was delicious, and I will be returning for my next sandwich in the park. BUT please please please no more sweet pickles for sandwiches! That was the only downside.
author: Puffin K.

description:
These guys certainly lucked out on Election Night. 

The spontaneous (?) street party that erupted at 19th and Valencia was in full force by the time my friends and I made it down there around 10:30, with folks celebrating Obama (dancing, shouting, marching bands, random conga lines, etc). You know, the usual.

Of course, with all this celebrating, it seemed few were (or wanted to be) sober. Enter Rhea's.

The liquor store is pretty small, and it was PACKED, but the owners were great. They kept the line moving quickly and everyone in a good mood. One of the owners/managers was even tossing out Oreos to people as we waited in line.

Minus one star for a funky floor plan. The middle aisle goes all the way to the wall, so navigating through the store (and getting two dozen people to line up) was a little awkward.
author: Tara B.

description: Probably the best sandwich shop in the city.  Katsu pork sandwich?  OOooOOoooOOooOOooh yeah!!!
author: Dan L.

description: Very good sandwiches at this corner market.  I recommend the Valencia Street and the Chicken Katsu sandwiches.  There are a lot of hipsters at this joint but then again, it's in the middle of the Mission.  Go for the sandwiches.
author: Eddie L.

description: This deli/liquor store epitomizes the Mission District of San Francisco....kinda hipster, pretty small, kinda random, but serves great flavors.  I loved it!  I ordered the Korean Steak Sandwich....it was massive.  Definitely could feed two easily.  The bread was alright, not the best I've had...but the melded flavors of salty, spicy, and sweet was heaven.  The meat was marinated well with lots of flavor and not too salty.  The extras that came with it like the pickled onions and grilled onions definitely went well with everything.  You get to choose the cheese, but it's hard to blend cheese with asian flavors...but who doesn't like cheese...so just go for it.  These Deli definitely serves unconventional sandwiches and allows the ingredients to shine without any frill.  Simply food done well makes for a happy belly.
author: Melanie S.

description: Not much to say about this place that hasn't already been said. First timers get the Korean BBQ sandwich and you will not be disappointed.
author: omid a.

description: This place is the best sandwich shop I've found since moving here!  It's got the quality of a great Italian or Jewish Deli in New York, but the soul of San Francisco.  The variety and great combinations should allow anyone to find a favorite, or at least make their own.  The wait time can be a little long, so it's best to call ahead, but when you walk down Valencia passing empty places and then see the crowd around Rhea's, there's a reason.
author: Drew C.

description:
Great sandwiches!
I like the Korean steak sandwich more than the Chicken katsu sandwich.
The grilled panini is good too!
author: George M.

description: This place has great sandwiches, the selection is quite diverse with the choice of making your own sandwich as well. The only problem I have with this place, and the reason I won't be going back is the wait time. Jesus....I ordered my sandwich at 3:15 and didn't get out of there until almost 3:45. I'm sorry, but what takes so long to make a freaking sandwich? I could see if they were baking the bread or maybe I'd cut them some slack if they had to go to a garden in the back and pick the lettuce, tomatoes and onions! But unfortunately, this isn't the case. They need to learn how to make good sandwiches, in less than 10 minutes. Until they do that, they get 2 stars. Its a SANDWICH people!
author: CHADWICK B.

description: Consistent great sandwiches!  My fav is the Korean Steak sandwich.  The sandwiches are much better than Birite and Ike's Place for me.
author: teatzar s.

description:
I cannot believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.  As far as sandwiches go, this is easily a 5 star place.  The Acme toasted bread: awesome.  The marinated beef: awesome.  Being able to choose how spicy: super awesome.  I'm just glad this place brings some heat where spicy is actually.. SPICY, and you can pick how spicy you want it to be.  Bunch of other stuff in there like cheese, onions, lettuce.

I almost always get the Korean BBQ sandwich ($8) and sometimes the pork katsu sandwich, and you can eat it at the counter by the front window (seats about 5?).  The service is friendly, and it takes about 10-15 minutes to make a sandwich.  They deliver in the Mission area via bicycle.

food prep area appears to be clean
service is great
parking is there
author: John D.

description: This place has delicious sandwiches. The guys behind the counter were super chill and nice. It took a bit longer than expected to get my sandwich made, but that's because they had a ton of orders to get through- a sure testament to their deliciousness!
author: Megan L.

description: Sandwiches are great, just not worth the wait. I will be back though. I just need to remember to pre-order.
author: Jessica M.

description: Just found out about this place.  Sad that I haven't been here before but will be a returning customer.  So many great sandwich options.  I think Ike's Place has some competition especially if this place has a shorter wait.  A definite must if you're in the Mission.
author: Bhavesh M.

description: Dang ya'll, this place is good.  My coworker recommended it and I can't stop going. The sandwiches are well worth the price. Huge, delicious, and well made. I am so glad I found this place.
author: Ashley M.

description:
A little over-priced, but what corner store isn't?

GREAT selection of booze! Microbrews out the woosie! 

Good stock of things to eat for those lazy days when a trip downstairs is all that can happen. Frozen foods, cereals, basics like flour/sugar....all in abundance. 

Deli? Not at all. They should really work on that name.
author: Danyell K.

description: We prefer the Katsu sandwich to the Bulgogi one.  The staff is always super friendlyL they have dog biscuits behind the counter for your poochie, and hazelnutty snacks for the humans while we wait.
author: Lisa S.

description: This is a very unassuming liquor store looking deli. I actually passed it by when I was walking alone the night before and was surprised when my friend took me here the next day for a sandwich run. We split the Korean steak sandwich. It's just as amazing as everyone else makes it out to be. Spicy, meaty, cheesy, and bursting with complementing seasonings. Make a lunch run of this place and you won't be disappointed.
author: Allen F.

description: delicious sandwiches, great veggie options. i prefer rhea's over ike's.
author: Roxy B.

description: I'm so glad this place isn't near my office or my home, or else I'd have to buy some new pants.  Had their chicken sandwich which came with a garlic aoili.  It's not just an ordinary sandwich and truly tastes like a fresh gourmet sandwich for a fraction of the price.  Oh, and no skimping on the portion sizes either.  This place is in a market, so it's not a sit down kind of place.  You walk in, fill out a piece of paper with your order, hand it to the counter person, and then wait a few minutes before you're whisked away into sandwich bliss.
author: Tara C.

description:
Pretty ordinary food. Sometimes hype just spins out of control. No doubt that Bi-Rite sandwiches are on a seriously higher level than this place, for about the same price. Good volume, though, if you just want to get full.

Sitting down at Dolores Park to eat my steak sandwich, I found it had some ordinary semi-stringy bulgogi on it and a few other ok ingredients, but it wasn't balanced and the flavors & textures didn't complement each other -- just a bunch of stuff chucked together in a lump, which is amateur sandwich making to be honest. 

The bread was good quality, so I picked out the meat, ate one side of the bread with the cheese and threw the rest in the garbage.
author: Nick C.

description: So they get a great review on Bay Area Check and I am a sucker for trying new places, bad idea !!  I get there at 11:30am and after I order and pay for my sandwich the cashier smiles and says "by the way 30 minute wait on the sandwich."  huh?  There were maybe two other people at the deli at the time I ordered, why the wait?  We got our sandwiches about 60 minutes later, good, but not worth the 60 minute wait.
author: Aida S.

description: AMAZING!! Been here a few times and for some reason never realized I needed to get one of their specialty sandwiches... wtf?!?!  Never go here and order a regular sandwich trust me you are missing out too!  I tried the Spicy Korean Steak Sandwich and it has changed my life, never again will I go to Dolores without a cider and a sandwich from here.
author: Jasmine D.

description: HA-- OVERRATED.  If you like your sandwiches bathed in a mess of garlic/mayo/etc. then you will be in heaven.  waited 35 minutes for blaaaaaaaah.
author: eshwar k.

description: I got the Korean Steak and it was really good. Great combination of spicy and sweetness with the marinated cut up steak. Only came here once and I really enjoyed it. Lots of variety of sandwiches. Plan to try a Katsu Sandwich or a Roast Beef Sandwich(19th Street) during my next visit.
author: Nelson G.

description:
Korean BBQ Sandwich. Nuff said.  I've never had a sandwich like this one.  I tell everyone that lives and visits San Francisco to try it.  They also have other asian inpired sandwiches like Chicken and Pork Katsu.  I think about this place ALL the TIME.  Cannot find anything close here in NY.

The place is also a munchie joint with a wide selection of chips and ritter sport chocolates to choose from.
author: Vinny L.

description: Get the chicken katsu! Fantastic sandwiches. And, just found out they deliver. Dangerous :)
author: Don L.

description: Best sandwiches in the city (and possibly the world).  Everything is fresh and I love the Acme rolls.  Everyone loves the Korean steak and the Katsu sandwiches, so I want to put a good word in for the 17th Ave. (chicken, pepperoni, spinach, red onions, mozzarella, marinara sauce, garlic aoli).  SO GOOD!!!  Also, I find it so odd there are some negative reviews about service.  Sure, there can be a long wait (the demand is probably higher than they expected, but I heard they were putting in a second counter to help with that).  Everyone who works here is ridiculously nice. In conclusion, you should eat here.  It's delicious.
author: Katie F.

description: As soon as I read in one Yelp review "This place is seriously what Yelp was made for", I knew I had to go. I walked here on the way home from work off a gut feeling that I knew it'd be worth it even though it was effing cold. I'd been in the liquor store before but never noticed the sandwich counter, don't know why. I ordered the vegetarian BBQ chicken sandwich with cabbage slaw, housemade pickled onions and tons of spicy stuff on this delicious organic Semifreddi's ciabatta and got it right quick. The hipster dudes who made it were really nice and friendly, and the store itself had awesome European chocolate goodies you don't normally see at places like that. I hurried home and ate the shit out of it. I'll probably come back this weekend. Plus, I heard through the grapevine that they DELIVER too!
author: Laura M.

description: Really, this is just your average liquor store/deli, but they have a vegan sammich that is just awesome. Spicy, but amazing.
author: Jordan F.

description:
Rhea's is seriously the best neighborhood corner store in the entire City! And I am lucky enough to live one block away....

The Choi family who own and operate the market are friendly and truly care about the neighborhood and its residents. James, the owners' son who now runs the store, has even attended local police meetings with me and other neighbors regarding some major safety concerns in the neighborhood and is also always willing to lend support by signing petitions and writing letters to government officials. James and his awesome crew are always friendly and keep the shelves stocked with essentials such as cat litter (no more long walks from Petco for me), milk and Odwalla OJ.  

The store itself is well lit and clean and the products are priced reasonably and on par with the large supermarkets - no price gouging here. Sadly, the super cute Pomeranian who slept behind the counter for years passed away but has recently been replaced by a new addition to the Choi family... the cutest baby boy!
author: Andrea K.

description:
If you're hungry, lazy and want great deli in a hurry, Rhea's is the place!
It was my first experience and Rhea took my phone order with a charming "welcome to my place" attitude.  The food arrived by messenger within the hour and it was absolutely fresh and delicious.
I can't wait to try all the goodies on the menu and make regular visits to this happy place.  Congratulations to Rhea and her staff!   Mary F.
author: Mary F.

description: Hubby and I popped in here on a whim for sandwiches the other day.  I had been reading the Yelpness about this place and it was on our list.  They did not disappoint.  The katsu sandwich was outstanding.  I ordered mine spicy and considered it mild.  Next time I'll ask them to kick it up a notch.   The added bonus of delivery from here makes Rhea's a total win.  Damned good sandwiches.  Nuff said.
author: Russell D.

description: Most excellent sandwichs you can get in the area. Since they started making sandwiches, I would not go anywhere else. The employees are super chill and I love the vibe.
author: Tony S.

description: The Korean Steak Sandwich is a god sent.  I don't think I have ever had a better steak sandwich.  The lovely thing is, it comes in the form of perfection.  There is no need to ask to "hold this" or "add that", we ordered the "hot" version and it was just that.  There were a couple of fatty parts I had to spit out otherwise, I would have given this place a 5.  They sell good chocolate, Perrier, and beer,  I don't need much else.
author: Jessica B.

description: Amazing food! And the workers are all pretty sexy! Van Ness is my favorite sandwich but they're ALL GREAT!
author: Lynsey M.

description: The Korean Steak Sandwich is quite possibly the best sandwich I've ever had.  The only reason for anything less than 5 stars are the limited hours during which this amazing sandwich is available.  When I work late, I would love nothing more than to grab one of these on my way home.  But alas, the deli closes at 5 on weekdays...
author: David F.

description: This place is so tasty! I am embarrassed to say I always go there requesting an adjustment to the dish (I am allergic to tomato and have recently given up dairy) and they are incredible at getting creative and bringing me delicious dishes I can eat. They really have a knack for surprising flavor combinations. Rhea's is most famous for their delicious sandwiches but they make incredible salads too.
author: D Z.

description:
this place is the underdog of delis.  fresh sandwiches with quality meat.  the bbq korean steak sandwich is absolutely phenomenal!  the flavors are seriously out of this world.  not a carnivore?  they have the bbq fake chicken version for you veg heads, and any typical sandwich one would crave.  they have a pork katsu sandwich that i'd like to try next.

the guys who work there are friendly and funny.  they have all the staples you need from a deli/liquor store.  

you need to try their sandwiches...they're that amazing!
author: Sheri N.

description: The amount of love and care that goes into each and every sandwich they make is impressive. I've been a few times since I found it earlier this year and I think this might be my new favorite sandwich spot. All their signature sandwiches have like 30 different ingredients in them... which, at first, made me think I'd be wearing it later. I was totally wrong. Much to my surprise and due to perfect ingredient distribution, everything stays in these sandwiches and doesn't fly all over the place. They've clearly spent a lot of time profiling these sandwiches because everything in them goes sooo well together. All their breads, vegetables, and meats are quality and really fresh.
author: Jason S.

description: Korean steak sandwich is awesome! Great flavoring of the beef and quite a bit of hear, but not overwhelming.  Also can buy and drink beer there. This isn't for the faint of hear though. It can be a little rough on the stomach if you know what I'm saying. If are walking through the area on the way to/from Zeitgeist this is a welcomed stop along the way!
author: Nicholas H.

description: I work a block away from this store, amidst numerous, eclectic eateries of the Mission district. Their sandwiches are my favorite around! They are amazingly FRESH, UNIQUE, COMPLEX, and DELICIOUS. My favorites are the pork katsu (asian style fried pork chop) with cabbage slaw, and the portobello mushroom panini. My coworkers crave the Korean steak sandwich on a regular basis. The cheese, sauces, mustard, pickled onions, arugula, etc. options for topping are endless. The owner and employees are always friendly, and the store carries quality food and drink for your basic corner store needs as well.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I've been waiting 45 minutes to have a person tell me they lost my order slip. Give your hard earned money to people who'll do the same. The person with the beard didn't care that this happened - just shrugged his shoulders.
author: Jay L.

description: Saw their review in The Chron. Saw the pictures.  I don't know what those folks got but it sure wasn't what I got.  Grey, tough brisket. And as the saying goes, very little of it.  Mostly hard, dry roll and a LOT of undressed veggies that were completely different than the menu promised.  The only dressing was smeared on the roll and spinach (not on the menu description) had been placed against it, whereupon the spinach turned to slime. No jicama slaw as promised.  All this with a high price and a 35 minute wait.  Why is it so difficult to get a decent sando in this area?
author: Linda H.

description:
I just finished having a Vegetarian BBQ sandwich from Rhea's for lunch. It was one of the best sandwiches I have had in a long time. Fresh cole slaw (thankfully lacking any sign of mayonaise), carrots, perfectly seasoned wheat meat, jalapenos, (I ordered medium spicy - if you want a milder version of this one, you can definitely order mild on their convenient order sheets or just ask them to leave out the jalapenos) which somehow were not overpowering on this,  and an absolutely delightful bbq sauce. 

I now plan to try all of their sandwiches - their signature sandwiches. They have an exciting, inventive list of sandwich creations listed on their menu.  For plainer fare, they also have it going on with Boar's Head cold cuts - the best!
author: Lauren S.

description: So I live directly across the street and make several several stops here daily.  At least 3.  I like seeing all the guys that work there.  They are awesome and friendly.  I have been going there since before they started serving food and since they have,  I rarely have to leave my block....the sandwiches are amazing the people are awesome and the price is right
author: Casey S.

description:
dont need to say much here.  the other reviewers before me were absolutely correct: the korean steak sandwich is amazing.  get it.  get it spicy.  get it now.  

i will return, maybe to try the pork katsu.  ill be hard pressed not to just keep ordering the korean steak sandwich, though.
author: Cyrus C.

description: My coworker had read about their korean steak sandwiches on a local blog and suggested we drop in during our lunch break.  Hefty portions of bul-go-gi and the toppings.  I had enough for both lunch and dinner.  I think next time I'll try the katsu sandwich.  Sandwich & drink came out $10.50. My Coworkers picked up a few jars of the home made kim chi on the way out.  The wait time was approximately 20 min which seemed a little on the long side, but well worth the wait.  I advise calling in your order ahead of time. Friendly service.
author: Stacey L.

description: Really good, spicy sandwiches.  I had the Pork Katsu and a friend gave me a bit of his Korean beef, which I will be getting on my next trip.  Both were really good, so it's going to be hard to decide. There's three or four seats just inside the door, so you'll most likely want to get it to-go.  We had placed our order ahead of time and they were ready to go when we got there.  All around a good lunch experience, and worth the trip out of SOMA, a quick BART ride, for a decent lunch.
author: Andy B.

description: Great deli sandwiches with huge selection. Perfect to take to go and sit in Dolores Park to eat.
author: Lina L.

description: I am so happy to have found another cute, friendly sandwich shop within walking distance of my house.  The menu isn't quite as exhaustive as Guerrero Market & Deli, but they do a great panini, and as long as they've got some form of turkey, I'm happy.  For the most part, sandwiches started at about $5 for meat & a reasonable number of veggies, & then some things cost extra (like cheese, avocado, getting panini-ed, etc.).  My turkey & cheese panini ended up setting me back around $8.  They also have a good selection of local wines, & plenty of beers, soda, & juices beyond the obligatory, which is nice.
author: Angela B.

description:
The only regret I have about letting my co-worker get me addicted to these sandwiches is that I don't have any money at the moment to buy more.

I rarely eat lunch these days, but after seeing my co-worker eat these sandwiches, I gave him $10 and had him pick up his favorite sandwich for me to try.  From the minute he walked back in the door, I was hooked.  The smell was intoxicating and was only topped when I took a bite out of the massive Korean Steak Sandwich.  There was no need for nicotine or another addictive substance; the wonderful blend of sauce, peppers, and meat did all that and more on it's own.

I've read through some of the lesser reviews which dock a star off here for Rhea's not originally being a deli, or for having "too big a sandwich" (which I have never heard of), and all I have to say is this:  Who cares?  When the food is this good, five stars is the bare minimum Rhea's deserves.  Bravo James!  Bravo!
author: Matt W.

description:
Limited seating, but they make some of my favorite sandwiches in SF.  I could go on and on and on about how great their sandwiches are.  

Currently, the chicken katsu sandwich tops my Bay Area sandwich list (I'm sure the pork is great as well).  It is perfect.  Start off with a fresh acme, role, add a crispy and rich fried chicken katsu, throw on some sweet and tangy pickled red onions and fresh coleslaw, and top it with that hot sauce - I don't think it gets any better.  Perfectly balanced and damn good.
author: Christopher C.

description:
they make a damn good sandwich. no joke. the korean steak... duh. i also like the 18th street (buffalo chicken) mmmmMMMMmmmm 

im pretty sure i'll get one for lunch today. :)
author: Ashley A.

description: I used to order from this place multiple times s week until there strict only 2 slices of bacon per sandwich rule was enacted i ordered a BLT Thats Bacon Lettuce and Tomato nothing else what i got the last time i ordered was a mound of lettuce a slice of tomato and 2 tiny pieces of Bacon seriously WTF!!! when i called to complain they said they could give me another sandwich (took 45 min to get first one) but that the 2 pieces of bacon was all they were permitted to use regardless of the order again are you f*cking  kidding me  ??? I also ocationally just get soda's and smokes delivered ( i am in a wheelchair due to broken neck and can't go out they were my lifeline) on a regular basis the seriously rudest girl answers the phone and basically told me my order is insignificant and unwanted who says that to a customer ? especially a regular ??? based on this i started using TCB who will literally bring you anything your little heart desires from noon till 10 all week (i love them ) today i decided to call and give reah's one last chance was going to order a sandwich some ginger ale and a pack of smokes before i can even say i would like to place a delivery order this snotty rude chick gets on and says cash only you using a cc sorry can't help you when i said no biggie will call TCB (they use them to deliver) they have there own cc machines with them She proceeds to tell me that TCB is working for them and would have to use her machine (which i know is a lie) so not to bother. Wow Reah's must be a super fun place to work when the drivers company gets basically badmouthed to customers by the deli staff Again there are a couple of pleasant people there who can be amazing but if there is a chick on the phone or behind the counter i guess you better watch out WORST ATTITUDE"S EVER !!!!!! Shame this place used to be amazing now i don't know anyone who still eats there due to the only good things on there menu being removed the horrible attitude of the counter staff and then there's the 45 min wait to get a frakin sandwich i worked in a deli for 5 yrs no deli sandwich on the planet takes 45 min and i could have whipped up the katsu one in about 5-15 depending if i cooked it from scratch if the stuff was pre made maybe 2 min flat Max and in a place like that there isnt a single dish that should take more than 9 min from order to served if they have a clue what they are doing. So to sum up don't go here unless you want to wait forever and be treated like shit Kinda like Zestiest but without any good parts ! An if you need pretty much anything delivered seriously call TCB they are amazing and the nicest people you will ever meet !
author: Kristen H.

description: Ordered the veggie chicken BBQ sandwich - amazing. Order it spicy, if you can handle it. Best I've ever had, better than Ike's sandwiches. $8.49 after tax. Friendly service. Highly recommended.
author: Karl N.

description: I love this place. The Korean steak is as good as they say. I also love the Van Ness, which involves the tasty chicken katsu. Even the fake chicken is damn good. I highly recommend the Acme roll and getting your sandwich "spicy" whenever possible. The people who work here are invariably friendly and cool. The stools in the back provide a surprisingly nice place to sit, and it's actually a reasonably priced convenience store to boot. You can save time by calling your order in ahead. And don't wait til too late in the afternoon because they do sometimes run out of stuff.
author: Marco L.

description:
Get the Korean Steak sandwich! There's a great deli at 19th & Guerrero that makes a mean tri-tip, but the Korean Steak sandwich at Rhea's is a better sammich. Sweet and tangy bulgogi (from mom's recipe) with house-pickled onions, homemade aoili, and a lovely mess of sandwich staples makes for a truly awesome meal.

Other highlights are the great microbrew selection in 12 and 22 oz bottles (and even 21st Amendment brews in cans), a breadth of cheap and tasty wines, and fresh local cheeses without the line or pretense at Bi-Rite.
author: Sean B.

description: Got the Judah St. This is just an all around solid joint.  Friendly service, delicious sandwich, quiet little area to sit and eat your sandwich while you people-watch on Valencia. I will definitely be back.
author: M M.

description: Best corner store in town.  James really took it to heart updating this cool store, and the results show.  Great new deli, awesome wine selections, tons of beer to choose from, and the coolest staff around.  They actually like working there!  Some of the best sandwiches in the city, reasonable prices.... and they carry everything i need to operate my day to day.  I shop there almost too often those guys a prob sick of me.   Try the the side dishes in the deli case they are fantastic.   Potato salad is unreal.  If you stop in for beer, wine, smokes, booze, sandwiches, TP, ice cream, or gum.  They've got your back.  word up to jesse, george, and jorge'.
author: andy c.

description:
i've only had one sandwich here so far, the korean beef sandwich, spicy.

they were out of both pork and chicken katsu, but rest assured i'll be back to try each of the sandwiches offered. i like sitting at the window seat bar people watching valencia and 19th street, while my sandwich drips on the wax paper.
author: Ameer N.

description: Had a Valencia, loved it.  Amazing combo of (very) crusty bread, amazing condiments and quality meat and cheese.  Took a while to make, but damned worth it.  The guys in the place were very cool.  The ability to co-purchase chips and beer is essential here.  Call in your order, grab a tall boy and some stupid colored sunglasses and enjoy your hipster-handmeal in Dolores Park.  Someone will have to create something pretty stinking spectacular to beat this sandwich.  And please, stop calling them "sando."
author: Eric S.

description: veggie bbq chicken sandwich FTW!!!!
author: rhiannon B.

description: You come here for lunch, you order the spicy Korean bbq sandwich, you go home and eat it, and fall asleep. When you wake up several hours later, go back for more.
author: Noah W.

description: Very good, very large sandwiches made fresh to order. Large variety of fresh ingredients. Very busy, so service is a bit slow. Also, the sandwiches are rather expensive, but since they are also very large, that's not unreasonable. Small grocery offers chips, cookies, drinks, and more.
author: Kate S.

description:
I live and work right next to Rhea's. Not only is it a joint I can wander into drunkenly and go up to the counter with their remaining stock of Smart Waters but they also make completely KICK ASS sandwiches. 

I was pretty excited when James told me he was going to start making sandwiches. Then he told me how he wanted as much of it as possible to be homemade and I went apeshit.

Basically, any of the specialty sandwiches they make are TO DIE FOR. Order it "Spicy as motherfuck" and they will not disappoint. BAM!
author: Nic P.

description:
we got two sandwiches. vegetarian bbq  and pork katsu. this was a month ago. we went to ikes but the line was fricken too long. 

all in all, i thought the sandwiches were OK. But maybe because I wanted Ikes...I will definitely go again for the pork katsu for a second chance without thinking of another spot!
author: Rachna P.

description: Great sandwiches, quality ingredients and everyone is super friendly. This family has owned this bodega for years, its really nice to have a quality meal without any of the gourmet ghetto drama
author: arin f.

description: The veggie BBQ sammich is hot hot hot~! Hugs for Rhea. My only beef, so to speak, is that there should be more veg options on the menu.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: This is a great little convenience store that has gotten me out of many a pinch - vinegar & baking soda for a clogged drain, popcorn kernels for a late night snack, and so on.  What really makes it stand out though is the great guys who work at Rhea's.  They're friendly, talkative, and don't act put out when you want a price check on something that isn't labeled.  Basically, they're cool as hell, and that goes a long way.
author: Josh C.

description:
got the korean bbq in a panic because they were out of everything katsu. i was going to try the one with chicken katsu and bacon...sounds good. but they were out! i panicked! just said korean bbq! spicy! later finding on the menu a salami sandwich that sounded kinda tasty.
anyway. korean bbq, not that spicey...and...just kinda...eh.
author: Nicole G.

description: I crave a sandwich from Rhea's on a weekly basis! I must admit that I only had the chicken katsu sandwich, but was definitely surprised and impressed with how many good flavors could fit into just one bite. There's a great selection of other sandwiches which looked tasty as well, so I'm definitely going back to try those. The portion was generous so you get your money's worth. Nice place to grab a sandwich on the way to the park.The guys in there are always friendly too! Last I was in there, they said they were delivering- right on!
author: Keegan M.

description: Delicious sandwich. Definitely worth ordering ahead in the middle of the day or else you'll be waiting a while.
author: Ezra C.

description: This secret little spot should have put Ike's Place out of business already. Between the Acme bread, cowgirl creamery cheeses and homemade Kim-chi they really hit it out of the ballpark.
